review_title: Business Banker at Citibank is a dead end job with no room for advancement.
pros: The job is better than most sales jobs. Or it used to be when Citibank was able to walk proudly down the street with its chest open, bragging about its ability to be a global brand. Now it's nothing more than a 4 dollar stock.
cons: Like any sales job you have some of the most unprofessional managers who seem to have got to their position through sheer luck or seniority.

review_title: Underpaid, Few chances to move within the organization
pros: They were great with Work-Life balance, and they were very flexible with all employees. Working from home was frequently an option if you had a conflict or bad weather, and work hours were very reasonable 95% of the time.
cons: Their pay is more than a 10% cut from the market rate, and raises have been less than cost of living over past 4 years.  They don't make it easy to move internally, and their hiring process leaves much to be desired.

review_title: Anti Money Laundering (AML) -  HIGH turnover, HORRIBLE culture
job_title: AML Operations/Compliance Analyst in Welland, ON
pros: Work from home two days per week (used to be three, see below); some wonderful, intelligent and helpful coworkers; branded / known company name on your resume; at times, interesting work that you can see the implications of.
cons:
Please, do yourself a favor and read the reviews for the city / position of interest that you are considering; additionally, pay attention to the posting date and similar, highly positive reviews that should be read with caution (HR has been trying to change external opinions to try to recruit more people, as they can't keep up with the high turnover rate - hence, the use of so many recruiting / contract companies). 

Hiring Process: As many others have stated, get EVERYTHING in writing that you are told; ask deeper questions regarding the "bonus" / "merit pay increase" / benefits, etc...They are not as advertised by the internal recruiters. You WILL be working more than 40 hours per week, EVERY week, contrary to the "...on rare occasions you may have to work a couple of extra hours" that is told during the hiring process (as you will find out at the beginning of training when you start hearing and seeing the real hours).

Culture and General Work: Very negative, depressing culture, from the top-down. I am a person who can find a positive in any situation, as are many great coworkers at CitiGroup, but after working 12-16 hour days and weekends (no overtime pay), and still being told by management that we aren't doing enough and need to work harder / faster, positives are hard to find; constant verbal threats about job security / performance plans, etc...without support or how they are going to fix the unreal work imbalance across the floor. After 1.5 years of working non-stop (including holidays from home), I had had enough and voluntarily resigned; I was the 29th person to do so in only 2 months! The Team Lead's will tell you how great you are doing on your cases and QA scores, etc...and then later that same day, tell you how you need to be doing more cases, although they know that you are putting in all of the extra hours and doing great work (?? - confusing, makes you feel defeated and frustrated? Yes!). 

Benefits / Pay: 20% below industry average pay and subpar benefits. Citi is an international, huge company, yet I the benefits were the worst that I had ever had working in various industries for 15+ years. Aside from the low pay, excessive hours and negative culture, plan for $82 - $98 to come out of your paycheck (for an individual) and still have to pay high deductibles / copays, for a healthy person.

review_title: Hope to get a good manager
job_title: Compliance Analyst in Copenhagen, Capital Region
pros: Great Work/Life balance; great benefits and the fact it's a global company gives you opportunity to work in many areas and possibly relocate (depending your level of management)
cons: This company needs to make sure that a people manager at a minimum has PEOPLE skills.  Too many managers roaming this company that are clueless on how to manage people.  This can stunt your grown with this company because if your manager doesn't know how to voice how much you do...well you are pretty much screwed.

review_title: Citi India - Great Place to Work
pros: Organization values talent, provides opportunity to grow, employee friendly, provides great options for mobility across business and geographically. Overall a great place to work
cons: It is no longer the top paymaster it used to be. Specifically due to India being one of the frontier markets, often Indian employees do not want to take on overseas role for lateral movements but only for larger roles leading to stagnation at top.

review_title: Global institution, but sector in turmoil
pros: Truly global institution  with many opportunities, Coverage of many sectors, economies, industries and products. Good contacts with influential people in industry and politics
cons: Finance as an industry has probably peaked and is now in the process of scaling down. Not sure whether the fat trimming is always done in the correct places; it seems still top-heavy with many senior administrators.

review_title: ok for the start of your career
job_title: Fund Accounting Analyst in Jacksonville, FL
pros: You can really grow within the company if you are motivated enough to stay for a few years. Young and dynamic people, great contact with direct management. Relatively good pay.
cons: Not a very challenging job. I did not feel like learning a lot, work was very repetitive and boring.  I did not feel there was enough training provided and at times I felt that people did not really know what they were doing and why. Long working hours - it was never possible to predict what time would we finish the work.

job_title: Vice President  in Long Island City, NY
pros: The vacation allowance is unmatched.
cons: Politics, lack of ownership, inefficient use of time and resources, not smart when it comes to knowing who the customer is, mass marketing, no challenge, you are just a big cog in a big wheel.  Can't accomplish anything because of the multiple levels you have to go through and the lack of capable technology.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Auckland, Auckland
pros: Pro:   Good benefits for this area.
cons: Phony employee recognition programs, feel good, touchy feely programs that become so rampant they don't mean anything. System is rigged so that the front line employee is always wrong, no matter how unrealistic management goals are.  Management pushes Great Customer Service, yet employee not given the time to GIVE good Customer Service. The VOE program (Voice of the Employee) has a lot of time spent on it, yet I did not feel that management really listened, just paid lip service. Also, the Morality of Citi being able to borrow from the Fed (even before its bailout) at low interest rates 2% or lower, and then turn around and lend that out at 28-30%  IS the definition of usury from the Bible, at least to me. I am glad to be gone from them.

review_title: Can be frusturating place to work
pros: Broad range of jobs if you want to explore opportunities,   Diverse employee population lends itself to working across many ethnic background and geographic areas.  The Global footprint allows for travel and opportunity as well and exposure to working with different regions.  Work can be what you make out of it.
cons: Silos exist and diversity in thinking can be a challenge as well as a benefit.  People do not seem to get rewarded for what they do but for what they say they do.  So a very pretentious incompetent individual could rise the ranks faster than a quieter more deadicated worker.

review_title: Good place if you are in the business side and not a support function.
pros: This is a very diverse bank which can provide great opportunities to in the area of choice. The UK staff are very professional and quite open. Especially if the individual is in the banking side rather than the support functions, it is very good.
cons: The size of the place makes it a problem for the individual contribution to make a significant impact on the larger scale. The recent problems in the market also make things a bit difficult.

review_title: Citigroup has gone from bad to worse.
pros: Decent salary as fair market pay goes.
cons: No fairness for time off for extra hours worked. No quality time for family life. They made billions in profits in 2010, but instead of giving a bonus or raise, they tried to have a company mandatory forum to ask people how they felt.  During the meeting when an employee tried to voice that concern, they tried to twist the words that the company had awards to recognized individuals and gave compensation. We NEVER heard of such programs. Maybe they do exist at the executive level? I guess that would make sense.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Dallas, TX
pros:
Benefits are very good
Easy and normal to work remote
Facilities are modern and clean
Chance to learn the latest technologies
cons: Because its a bank, security and auditing are more important than making sure we can backup/restore the computer systems.  This is evident in the amount of paperwork needed to get anything done.  Often given projects to deliver that are late before the paperwork was started which means everything gets escalated.

review_title: Huge company with endless job opportunities.
pros: they have great benefits and, most importantly, have benefits for same-sex couples. also, there are a bunch of changes they make and if you like things constantly changing, then this is a great place for you.
cons: collectors do not make a lot of money, but there is bonus potential. the problem is that you don't learn everything there is to know about what you have to do to bonus. there are particular things you have to do to get credit, which is not taught in the classroom.

pros: Its a great experience to be working with such experienced professionals in a fast paced environment. Work life balance is actually great, and while you have to give and take a bit over public holidays if you're covering markets across different parts of the world, you have a lot of freedom to choose your holidays. Hours are also not bad, given its markets - start early and finish early. Office culture is relatively casual, but very friendly and open.
cons: The training and guidance is fantastic at the very junior level, and there are always people to guide you if you reach out. The downside to this is that these sorts of opportunities are quite condensed at the very start of your career.

review_title: Great place to work, but you've got to be aware of the Changing Culture.
pros: Citi has a global presence and so, potential opportunities in many places around the world - if you are looking to start over or launching your career  in a new setting.  The technology side is quite tight, little or no wriggle room, and the green grass appears to be turning brown. Greater potential lies on the business/retail side.
cons: One of the greatest asset working here was the Work Life balance. That is quickly varnishing.

review_title: A mixed bag, depends on what you're looking for.
job_title: Balance Sheet Control Analyst III in Minnetonka, MN
pros: In my small area, I have a great deal of autonomy, I enjoy the people I work with and the environment, as well as the work.
cons: Most of the company does not have this, corporate nonsense is rampant, things are constantly changing (not for the better), and doing things a certain way is valued more than doing them correctly.  Company claims to be a meritocracy but then doesn't give raises.

job_title: Senior Vice President in Jersey City, NJ
pros: It is a great place to work with so many opportunities - even with all the orderliness and automation, there is still a lot of work to be done
cons: It is hard to motivate consultants - especially offshore - since many of them under Fixed Pricing contract - they really don't care. They do their shift and they take 3 breaks and are constantly away - Many teams throw the fire and walk away, not adhering to the policy and procedures and wait till the last minute; making some teams bend over backwards to accommodate the requirements.

pros: Great company to work for with management, and a tone at the top who care for the employees and make every effort to reward those trying to add share holder value and protect the interests of their consumers.
cons: As with every bank comes uncertainty and challenges that employers must work through.  Currently, the subsidiary that I work for within Citi recently announced that it will wind down operations and close the Bank.

pros: Citi is a great company to work for with a lot of opportunity for growth, the benefits are really great and you get a lot of paid time off including 48 hous of sick paid time off. They were extremely flexible with time off for school, I earned my bachelors degree while working there
cons: Working in retail customer service over the phone, just like anywhere else really sucks. Management set unrealistic goals and constantly changed things which made the job even more annoying. It's the call center life though you can't expect much

pros: "Can-do" New York H-Qed Bank with huge geographic footprint. Diverse, competent, professional people. On the whole very collegiate and friendly - an interesting and fun place to work. Lots of "extra-curricular" activities and a good CSR focus. Excellent transaction banking and services divisions.
cons: Very diverse product sets so difficult to achieve consistently good culture  across the whole -  e.g. investment versus transaction banking.   Can be bureaucratic. Loyalty penalized in terms of salary - long-term employees can be taken for granted.

pros: fair pay, great benefits and cafeteria
cons:
Loud and cramped call center, no personal space. Very immature workers especially the trainers.  "unit managers" don't even leave their desks, they just do the numbers.
Angry customers because their technology is so bad people can't even log in or register their cards online.   CSR's are not trained for all the stuff you have to know.   They outsource a lot of the departments overseas and there's a high turn over.  Stressful job that is not worth losing your health over.

job_title: Assistant Vice President  in London, England
pros: I joined Citi to travel and have moved two locations in the three years have been here. The place is amazingly diverse. Talented, hard working folks who generally know their stuff. There is name recognition and grudging respect in the outside world. Unlike other regional banks, respect for diversity is significant - no glass ceilings.
cons: Smaller offices (like Dubai) are very ethnically driven and power centres depend on the ethnic background of the local CCO. Levels of competence vary dramatically and the place is top-heavy. Support functions, especially Human Resources are plain incompetent. While the organisation claims to have more programmers than Microsoft, one would never know - hence Tech and Operations are fossilised.

review_title: Citi is OK but struggling to find itself. Upper management changes too often and totally changes corporate direction.
pros: It's a well known firm with multiple positions and opportunities. It provides good benefits and competitive salaries. If they ever figure out what they want to be "when they grow up"poor  they might regain the respect of their employees.
cons: Poor management skills from middle management on up. Sales programs are instituted and closed before they realistically can be evaluated. Too much time is spent on counting widgets instead of developing relationships with clients. Very poor morale among employees.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: A lot depends upon your manager.  Assuming one has a good manager, one can almost define his/her role by taking on as much responsibility as possible.  If one has the aptitude and drive getting exposure to technology, quants, analytics, trading desks, etc. are all within reach.  Internal mobility is supported and encouraged.
cons:
Because this is a very large organization, there is a need to cooperate with many peripheral groups and coordinate schedules and project plans.  There are formal meetings and processes to accomplish this, but it also helps to have a good network of friends when you need favors.

Even top performers are seeing compensation compression in these difficult economic times.

review_title: Like very high stress, backstabbing, and low pay?
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tucson, AZ
pros:
they have really good medical benefits, fmla, short term disability, vision, and dental, 401k matching
worked with some great people
cons:
office politics
high turnover
very stressful environment
employees doing the right thing are treated shabbily even though co policy is "do the right thing"
work environment is very structured
expect to get backstabbed by management
watch out if you make a higher wage than entry level –they’ll find any excuse to get rid of you to save a buck (bonuses are hard to come by even if you qualify)
they promote advancement opportunities - but not many see any
wage is not median w/the rest of the USA or even locally

pros: Benefits, especially vacation time, are good. Matching program is decent. Training program is good. Most staff members truly care about what they do.
cons: Longer your are there, the worse the pay. 10 years, 2 pay freezes, no bonuses, and 2-3% increases (if you are lucky) doesn't help pay the bills. They are quick to hire from the outside then to promote within in some areas and sometimes, that person is paid a lot more than the current, company savvy person they overlooked.

review_title: Nice place to start a career but not to have a long-term career!
pros: Work-life balance was available if you asked. Plenty of opportunities within organization for career and advancement.
cons:
Management turnover - too many high level managers leaving or taking new roles. It's like being on a boat without a rudder - trying to all paddle as hard as you can, but unable to get anywhere because you can't maintain a true direction!

Really screwed long-term employees by heavily touting stock ownership, forcing stock as part of bonus and then turning around and dilute shares by 90% with reverse split!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV
pros: In the more than five, less than ten years I worked there my compensation more than doubled. Company kept us throughout the recession. Was eventually laid off with the rest of the staff, but received months of notice and a lot of support through the process. Contacts at this company actually helped me get my next job. Lots of opportunities to move around and advance, very supportive culture.
cons: Nothing really jumps to mind. Life after Citi makes it apparent how good you had it, because no job will ever do more to take care of you than they will. Note, I was a very low ranked employee. When the people on the bottom can say that, you're doing something right.

job_title: QUALITY SPECIALIST II in Boise, ID
pros: Benefits and job security are good. Tuition assistance, and time off make working here a little more acceptable. Possibility to grow with the company if you know the right people.
cons: Working in a call center makes for long days that are always the same. Customer are rude because they don't have to look you in the face. If you are ok working with ungrateful customers regardless of the situation this is the job for you. Schedules usually are not great and it is a lot like being somewhere between a high school and a grade school. Job is easy and repetitive.

review_title: Works on perception employee should be careful about that in GDM Blr
pros:
Work culture is good
Pay and benefits are good and they pay well above Market level
Work is good and best thing is they encourage innovation
cons: Main problem: You should be cautious to save your reputation once you loose it you will be ignored, so will be your growth. Some ppl involve in bad politics for the same.  I mean a 3 can become 1 performance wise but perception wise he will be 3 because of his reputation.

pros: Citi provided me with many opportunities for professional growth.  If you are a leader, they will give you new tasks or special projects.  The job was challenging and exciting, and Citi rewards good performance.  I was appreciated for the value that I brought to the company.
cons: Citi can have a very structured and hierarchical reporting/working structure even thought they have been working for years in breaking down barriers and silos.  New York staff tends to be competiive and individually focused. However, I do understand that in NYC operations, the stress may be greater.  Colleagues outside of New York are much more focused on teamwork, supporting each other and working together.

pros: There are some good people who work at Citi and if you are in the right location, you can have a plethora of job opportunities and experience (New York and Florida are ideal).  Good benefits.
cons: Very little diversity among company seniors and execs, many of whom have been around for 20+ years, can be very brash with "subordinates" and carry large egos.  If you are not in a particular demographic, you may not have much possibility for advancement.  Lots of ethical issues yet in response to the guilty pleas and fines, there are no leaders exiting.  Leaders often commit to deadlines sans input from team and end up requiring folks to work 12 - 14 hour days.

pros: Lots of opportunities to learn, very large financial institutional with tons of opportunities for promotion and development, good pay & benefits. Good and motivated team members from diversified backgrounds.
cons: Citi is due to its size a slow moving cruise ship, and therefore strategic management vision is needed. Unfortunately, the senior executive manager in charge  (RZ = MD of Banking Book Portfolio Management) is not very sophisticated, and has no real understanding of current issues affecting the banking book. He still uses old school risk management techniquesrelying solely on limits and diversification; no proactive management with a lack of focus on impact liquidity shortage on banking book, extreme emerging risks, systemic default chains, credit transfer pricing, etc. The MD maintains an ivory tower mentality with no real reach-out to the business partners and other stakeholders.

job_title: Call Center Customer Service Representative in Gray, TN
pros: Professional environment, ACTUAL care and concern for the clients and customers, Fantastic benefits, amazing ways to give back to the community, no DRAMA (finally a job without one!) , teamwork and helping one another here is definitely a big thing, we look out for each other! Every day is a good learning experience, there is no blatant backbiting or tearing each other apart.
cons: Work/Life Balance is very off, all of my life is pretty much devoted to this job...I'd love it if I could get more time to spend with my friends and family and time to get things done (However, Citi does its best to provide that if they can, and they usually can most of the time).

review_title: Credit Judge for No Preset Spending Limit cards
job_title: Credit Judge in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Friendly, great training program, good benefits, good people to work for and with.  Good supervisors, good feedback on work.  Always someone willing to help if you have questions.
cons: Schedules were not the greatest but they weren't the worst either.  Working 4 10 hour days was hard at first but once I got used to it it was great because I was commuting 40 miles one way to work so it was less for gas usage.

job_title: Trades Processing Representative in Getzville, NY
pros: Fairly independent work environment, get your portion done each day and no one will bother you really. Pay is decent, nothing special unless you come in with above average work experience.
cons: Growing/moving pains as Citi pulls many roles out of NYC and moves to Buffalo. From what I've heard, they figured out they can pay someone to do the same job in Buffalo much less than someone in NYC. Rare to get a quality manager, most are overworked and extremely on edge/irritated. Advice: ask meaningful questions during interview to learn about your manager to see if you'd fit under their team.

pros: Many different sales and trading areas to choose from and large presence in most markets
cons: Not a very collegiate environment for interns relative to other big banks, starts with human resources being very impersonal and experience is very dependent on what rotations you end up with, which you have very little control over.  Although they ask what rotations you are interested in, they don't assign you to them.

review_title: Excellent financial service firm to work for
pros:
- Good pay
- Work/life balance
- Free transport facility to anywhere in Pune (although it's a pain for few remote or far-away areas)
- You'll get to dive in some of the latest technologies (for most departments) and the learnings will be fantastic
- You get to drive the vendor to deliver tasks and projects
- Work with fellow employees, who also have been through very rigorous recruitment processes
- A great brand for other investment banks (I could get in to other captives very easily given my experience at Citi)
cons:
- Very hierarchical organization, you need to get approvals for petty tasks
- Not very dynamic, employee mobility may be limited
- Graduate Trainees will be honored more than the other employees

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Irving, TX
pros: Great benefits, perks, and environment.
cons: Yearly raises don't exist so you better get every penny you can going in! Lots of obstacles and catch 22's when trying to move up from within. They have programs, and things set up to appear helpful for growth, but they are for saving face, and should be taken at face value kind of like a fully stocked grocery store in North Korea. As an example I went for a promotion in a different department; they told me I needed a cert to move to that department, I asked if I could get tuition reimbursement or help obtaining that cert. They replied they could only reimburse the cert if I was in that department.

job_title: Technology Analyst in Jersey City, NJ
pros: The Technology Analyst program at Citi allows recent grads to have a decent variety of experiences within Citi in software. Citi has nice culture, people are generally very agreeable. If you get placed on the right team, you can get great experience.
cons: There are also a decent amount of teams that are not great to be placed on, it is difficult to control how this happens, so experiences can be hit or miss. (I personally know some who would not give the Technology Analyst Program at Citi this rating)

pros: Large company means better chances at being able to advance career without having to switch companies.
cons:
Working for a large bank means you're viewed as more of a cog in the machine, rather than an individual worker.  Common practice here is to hire a large quantity of employees to tackle high volume but then once the volume diminishes, conduct layoffs in response.  
Working mortgage means job stability is often dependent on how the overall market rates are doing.

review_title: Asset Servicing (Corporate actions) Germanics and Iberia
job_title: Corporate Actions Analyst in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Good location, Enthusiastic colleagues, gain experience in basic activities in Corporate actions on an entry level after graduation.
cons:
No training provided at all: I had no experience in the finance sector, so it was hard for me to pick up all the knowledge on the go while being under constant pressure. It was a struggle as the management did not provide any support at all.
The policy by Citi is to hire young enthusiastic people and spoil them all instead offering some improvement. Does not make any sense to me!
Hugh fluctuation due to such issues in the Germanic corporate action bay.
Be aware, management is dangerous!

review_title: Good Growth, Friendly People, Not great pay rise
job_title: Senior KDB Developer, Assistant Vice President in Pune
pros: Citi is overall a good place to work. Good work if you prove your potential. Lots of leaves. Friendly peers and superiors. Sometimes, you get to do boring work but that's part of the job.
cons: Yearly hikes are not great in tech roles 10% pet year if you are good. Bonus is ok compared to other Banks, But When you compare other hedge funds and prop trading firms, bonus is very poor. But I think that's how Banks and other fintech firms compare. If you stay long and perform well, you will grow on the leadership ladder but not monetarily.

review_title: Total of 7 years of service (in and out over the years). The worst work environment.
job_title: Vice President IT in Tampa, FL
pros:
Benefits and salary at market.
Ability to work remote some days of the week depending on your job.
cons:
Worst work environment I found in my career (over 30 years).
Internal culture is trying too hard to adapt to younger generation mentality in the most unproductive ways.
Lots of focus on "How do you feel" and little on "What are the facts". 
Lack of consistency and coherence from upper management.
Lots of managers came from technical positions and have no ability to manage people effectively.

review_title: Good place to gain valuable industry experience with nice people.
job_title: Client Support Associate in New York, NY
pros: The people there are nice and willing to help most of the time. There are a lot of resources for career advancement assuming the individual is a self starter. Managers are good at going over goals and making sure employees know where they stand. The health and retirement benefits are very good. There is plenty of interesting and challenging work.
cons: There too many separations of the businesses so there are some issues navigating the corporation. There is a lot of bureaucracy to work around. There is no set training (at least in the position I was brought into) for new employees.

pros: Great salary for the position and area. Better benefits than most companies. Constant reports of what's going on and the status of the company.
cons: Management isn't very good and often hard working individuals are overlooked and not recognized. Your not allowed to promote your own wares like girl scout cookies, yet you are "strongly" encouraged to engage in their charities.

review_title: Generally a great place to work, but there are some cons...
job_title: Vice President/Director in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Multitude of opportunities available
creativity is encouraged
good benefits
cons: Size of the company (i.e bureaucracy), frequent management changes, and outdated technology prohibit CitiMortgage from becoming best in class.  Numerous acquisitions over the past decade contributed to tremendous growth and some economies of scale, but integration activities of these acquisitions dominated the workload,  rather than improvements in processes, technology, and true innovation..

review_title: Focus on rebuilding a global financial services company
job_title: Managing Director in New York, NY
pros: Global footprint, many people with a global mindset, respected by customers (more so in the emerging markets), broad spectrum of products and customer capabilities.
cons: Senior Management is unable to engage with the many dedicated and talented people. 'Who' you know seems to matter more than 'what' you know. Poor information systems leaves the management floundering in the dark. Opinions matter more than facts - politics and tribalism more important than abilities. Not customer centric at the global level, so the franchise is being neglected in preference for financial engineering.

review_title: Great people, but disorganized, and lousy compensation/recognition
job_title: Director in Long Island City, NY
pros: Most of the people I work with are smart, selfless, and not political. There are opportunities to take on new roles, even in other departments. Management seems to be supportive of this.
cons: It is a very disorganized place which is constantly changing. Executive love PowerPoint, and it makes it difficult to get real work done. Compensation and recognition are not very good.

review_title: Very good if you're lucky to have a supportive boss
pros: Benefits are good. They take care of people they like but you have to make sure your higher ups know just how good you are. Opportunities, financial and otherwise, were much better prior to the financial crisis.
cons: Teams are very lean which means sometimes it's hard to take time off (no back up). The organization structure, which is global, sometimes makes it very bureaucratic in decision-making or instigating change. Similarly, sometimes regional or global initiatives are forced into local business even if they don't have a culture fit.

pros: Very flexible with schedules, great benefits, and pie job.  I enjoyed that I could go to school and work full-time, which is a luxury now.
cons: Management issues, no opportunity for growth, and you can easily get burned out.  The job was stressful because of your peers, not because of the actual job.  When the economy tanked, so did morale and management understanding that in our department, which was a LOSS department, collecting money was going to be harder than normal.

review_title: It's tough being an analyst, but Citi was good for me
job_title: IB Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
+ Global firm
+ Exposure to all financial instruments
+ Ability to move to different offices - both domestically and also internationally
+ Not as focused on which school you attended as other investment banks
cons:
+ Lost a lot of senior managers during the downturn as their equity became worthless
+ M&A often run by M&A team only with coverage providing support
+ Lacks prestiege of Goldman, Morgan - impairs exit opportunities
+ Long hours

review_title: You learn a lot about office politics and the importance of brown nosing.
pros: Great benefits and great pay.
cons: You can not trust HR to resolve issues, the management style is based on fear, intimidation, and condescension. Senior management is very fickle and have no idea how to develop, train talent, or retain talent. There is no work/life balance, and your personal business affairs will suffer.

pros: I work part time, 20 hours a week, really relaxed environment, management will bend over backwards to accommodate my school schedule. They have been fantastic to me over the years, excellent benefits through Manulife, unbeatable for part-time work and flexibility.
cons: Monotonous job, negatively toned conversations with clients, its like you start on the wrong foot with every conversation, takes a lot of patience and the ability to be able to handle these clients and turn them into a positive conversation and relationship.

review_title: Good company, tough times for a big bank
pros: Lots of bright people and a good culture of mentorship, lots of resources and established knowledge base/businesses, big client base, good work/life balance
cons: It's easy to get swallowed up in such a large company, lots of systems (technology support groups) are slow, out of date, ineffective, and Byzantine.  Harder to get promoted in the current environment.  Regulation has made a lot of seemingly innocuous activity potentially a violation, and you could be on your own to make legal arrangements if the regulators come after you or the firm

pros: The company pays well, and management at my facility was good at enabling employees.  Overall, I thought my position was a good starting posting.  I left, but my friends who stayed moved up so getting stuck doesn't seem to be a problem if you are ambitious.
cons: Training wasn't what it could have been so being consistently curious is necessary.  Sometimes people in the upper levels would take things out on the back office, but there were no obvious issues there.

pros: I've recently started at Citi and I feel right at home. Its great to be a part of such a massive, multicultural company. My immediate team is very friendly and supportive. They go out of their way to sort things out for me. I am allowed to work from home if I feel like it. The office building  is incredible, huge and uplifting. Even the security people in the lobby are lovely. Tonight for example on the way out they told me to be careful because it's very windy. Simple things but they do make you feel happier at work.
cons: I can't see any. I'll wait for a couple of years :-)

review_title: Good opportunity for growth but pockets of legacy behaviors which is detrimental for company
job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Opportunity to advance, pay decent, ceo and few other senior leaders committed to doing the right thing and has bought into vision.
cons: Some senior managers are still operating under old mentality and manages their org in a silo to rest of company. Compared to other big banks I would say Citi senior managers don't care about their employees and only seek to get the most out of them instead of a two way relationship.

review_title: Offers a good learning experience and work life balance
pros: Learning has be given utmost importance by my manager. The quality of work has been as per expectation of my profile. The package is decent enough. The work life balance is good and the company offers flexibility for working.
cons: The compensation package is decent but not as per it's competitors. No parity is maintained and a lot of times very average candidates are given much more than knowledgeable and more experienced existing employees. Travel opportunities are limited and going up the ladder is not smooth.

review_title: Not a bad place to work for
pros: So many areas to work in to find what you like as you build your career. Decent chances of getting a good work-life balance. 401(K) matching. Pretty decent health plan. Vast library of online training available for employees, including Udemy.
cons: Information is not easy to come by though attempts are being made to make information searchable. 360 degree review is still not implemented completely or soaked in the culture enough to make it useful across the org structure.

pros: Great Benefits and offers a variety of products!
cons: Short staffed and spread very thin.  Some  branches are closed on Saturdays so if you happen  to be working in a branch that is open on Saturday, you're expected to work 6 days a week.  No work/ life balance.  You become burnt out especially when you are putting in 8-10 hrs. Weekdays!

review_title: Good foot in the door, corporate culture outdated
pros: Team members are very knowledgeable. Pay is reasonable but can stagnate. Training and growth is encouraged with numerous opportunities for internal networking and jobs. Management does listen to concerns and often tries to actually do something about it.
cons: Though there is a push for innovation, it isn’t often adopted. Very silo-ed work environment, despite efforts not to be. Like most corporations, sometimes it ends up being “it’s who you know, not what you know.” Budgets come from the highest level-some departments get much more than others.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Tampa, FL
pros:
Vacation time & PTO, good health/dental/vision benefits, decent internal perks like gift cards for completing health challenges. One of the biggest benefits is a flexible/remote schedule that allows a lot of opportunities to work from home. 

Overall there's a lot of great people here & most of them will go out of their way to help you if you're looking to learn & not just being lazy. It's a great place to learn, expand your network (if you're willing to put in the time) and gather experience.
cons:
The proverbial red tape is endless. With a company this size it stands to reason, but it can be EXTREMELY difficult to make progress, conclude decisions or get agreements. Teams can be somewhat fragmented, in that team building events may be plentiful for one group & non-existent for another, even if they're in the same reporting hierarchy. 

Some reviews rave about the work/life balance here, but that varies heavily by what team you're on. Anything AML is out of control, especially in North America driving projects. It's not atypical to be expected to drive projects like a PM while getting paid like a junior analyst.

pros: The industry is exeperiencing unpredencted change at the moment.  It's exciiting to work for a firm whose goal is to lead the industry through one of the most signifcant macro-economic events in history.  The firm's world headquarters are located in the same city that I live in and that makes the commute fairly tolerable.
cons: The industry is exeperiencing unpredencted change at the moment.  It's difficult  to work for a firm whose goal is to lead the industry through one of the most signifcant macro-economic events in history.  The firm's world headquarters are located in the same city that I live and that means that I have to drive to work.

pros: Citigroup  has decent benefits, generous time off policies with 25 days off a year. The work atmosphere is still fairly relaxed even with the current atmosphere. If you are in the financial services industry, Citigroup is a fair bet at this time. Citi is too big to fail and if you are not part of the layoffs your employment is safe.
cons: The current financial crisis limits your options and and bonuses and merit increases. Also the Citi brand has been seriously tarnished by the financial crisis. The Citi brand as one of the most admired and trusted brands globally has been seriously damaged.

job_title: Collections Representative in Kansas City, MO
pros: alot of paid time off, enjoy working with peers. good hours!!
cons: not very positive enviroment, no one knows whats going on, ever!!! you try your hardest but its never good enough for them. you fail your calls for the dumbest reasons!!!!!! no incentives ever, they make it to where you can never get incentives. you get to the point with this job, you want to give up.

review_title: Exactly what you would expect from a big bank
pros: As a multi-national firm, Citi offers a wealth of opportunities to work in many different locations or interest areas.  You will find talented people throughout the company and there is a well-defined track into upper management.
cons: As in any large organization, Citi is not free of its bureaucracy.  Especially during the financial crisis, the bonuses were cut, changes weren't widely accepted, and the general culture was surrounded by fear of layoffs.

review_title: There are a lot of smart people at Citi, but it a fundamentally beuracratic and disfunctional company
job_title: Senior Vice President in Dallas, TX
pros: Generally good people.  Comprehensive benefits
cons: Compensation heavily skewed toward senior management.  Pay freezes for the last 5 years are not uncommon.  Generally new hire salaries are significantly more than what an existing employee gets, because they pay what they have to what the job commands on the open market.  Company has excellent benefits, but is intensely stingy, no parties, no cups in the break rooms, no knick knacks, birthday recognition - nothing.

pros: I got the needed job title to be able to move into a much better position in a different company.
cons: People are treated like any other piece of office equipment. The only way to get advancement was to be liked by managers. Skills were not valued. I watched people who could do a terrific job get pushed aside because a lead did not want the competition. They had the ear of the manager and were able to say what they wanted, without regard to the truth. This really surprised me, I thought a place like Citi would have better HR/management safeguards in place.

review_title: Many opportunities, but difficulty to attain them due to so many layers and red tape within such a large organization
pros: Opportunities to network with other divisions because most of management is willing to meet for a chat.  Many global locations allow the possibility to move geographically, but requires networking on your own.  No formal process
cons: Many layers of management which they are trying to improve.  These layers also cause miscommunication and specialized knowledge where most employees only know about there own role.  Very few individuals have a true sense of what goes on holistically at the firm.

pros: They have competitive pay, a fantastic benefits package that starts on day one, and an open and accepting workplace. The facilities are nice and clean, and everyone I worked with in upper level management was friendly and professional.
cons: Things change constantly, and sometimes it can be a challenge just to keep up. The company relies heavily on "alerts" that come through your PC to update you on changes, but if the call volume is heavy, you sometimes don't have time to look through the articles.

pros: I had a great learning experience, good work environment and excellent coworkers. Had the opportunity to escalate my way to the highest position available in my area within 3 years. The benefits were great: 401K, time-off, tuition reimbursement, just to name a few.
cons: Healthcare and compensation is somewhat on the low scale. Tasks get repetitive quickly and for someone looking for challenges, it gets boring. Specialized units and bureaucracy makes the operation look clumsy. They are always behind on the latest technology industry standards.

pros: Reasonable working hours during non-peak reporting periods, boss was kind and understanding.  Working hours varied by department, my department was a regular 9 am - 6/7 pm, which I liked.
cons: Difficult for newcomers to fit in, especially young ones. Some colleagues were dead wood, unfair distribution of workload among the team, but boss turned a blind eye. Lack of proper handover of tasks and support to newcomers. Loyalty was seldom rewarded. Compensation nothing remarkable.

review_title: Great Developmental Opportunties, Lack of Upward Mobility
job_title: Business Control Specialist in Florence, KY
pros:
There are many pros of working at Citi including:
-Opportunity to work with a great group of colleagues
-Work was challenging and rewarding at the same time
-A lot of opportunities to "own" your work
-Great work life balance
-Great benefits (healthcare, 401K match, etc.)
cons: While there are many opportunties to develop your  skill set for the next role, finding the next role is often difficult and requires dedicated time to find those roles by  yourself.

pros: Management is very knowledgable and well trained! Work policies are much better than competitor banks e.g work remotely, lenient with days off, some depts flexible with work schedule as long as full 40 hours worked each week. PTO begins immediately upon hire and company treats employees very well!
cons: Salary is not as high as competing banks offer, causing many talented employees to leave for more $$ elsewhere. Too many entry level workers do bare minimum, causing more intelligent employees to want to leave to be surrounded by likeminded individuals.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: The work itself is very high level and mentally stimulating, you will never be board. There will always be projects pilling up on your desk. People there are busy, but willing to help if you pull their ear - very diverse culture.
cons: Citi's management gives little to no direction to their employees, since they are overworked themselves. The working environment is the not good, most employees work in a cubical on a floor with 200 + employees. There were lines for the bathroom. Expect to work 10+ hours a day and to figure the company out on your own. It is very important to network and have your "go to people" to get things from.

job_title: Senior Vice President in Warren, NJ
pros: Flexible work, wide selection of projects
cons: Moving all IT from NY/NJ to TX

pros:
colleagues
salary
location
some internal events
gym on site
cons: management, too stressful, hard to progress, dull (not a lively place), training given, high turnover and some more, food is always the same and expensive

review_title: Outstanding company but no productive and loyal long-serving employees are not treated well
pros: Global presence, excellent career opportunities, good benefits
cons: Senior management gets hoodwinked by 'experts' in the audit risk and compliance world who are only 'papering the cracks' but do not provide any long-term, sustainable solution for the banks problems!

review_title: Great for people that love people
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Benefits are fantastic , they are true to their motto of wanting and celebrating diversity, family oriented environment, hard workers are noticed and given recognition.
cons: Just like any other corporate position, you gotta kiss butt before you can “kick” it- so for the introverted and prideful person, in regards to career advancement opportunities, might not be the best place for you. Lots of micromanaging- depending on your manager.

job_title: Associate Quality Analyst in O'Fallon, MO
pros: Citi cares about their employees.  They give you time to volunteer for charities during your busy week.  There are Diversity Networks that you are encouraged to join to learn about others around us.  There are multiple days throughout the year that Citi gives back to their employees with "Fall Festivals" or give a-ways.  They work hard to have a good morale throughout the building.
cons: There has been some restructuring in the past year and many people have been laid off.  This is not good for morale at all.  I feel like Citi prepared these people pretty well for what was coming their way, but it is still not easy.

review_title: Good place to work if you can hold on to the job in this economy
job_title: Senior Engineer in New York, NY
pros: A lot of flexibility on the technology side. As long as the problems were solved very little or no red tape to go through. The managers were not very pesky.
cons: Getting things cross teams is a nightmare. The back office is probably one of the reason they were unable to compete with other IBs even during the boom time.

review_title: Stay for the pay until you can find a place where you don't feel like pucking every morning before going to work.
job_title: Senior Software Architect in Frankfurt am Main
pros: The pay is OK. The offices in Frankfurt are very well located close to the Opera house. If you want to move to London, it's a good platform, also for pepople who love finance....
cons:
Bad management. Bad work conditions (lack of space), very little attention was given that we barely had enough elbow space to work and the noise levels in the office was always very high. 
Management does not understand technical issues. 
The heavy use of outsourcing to India is an another problem. 
The outsourcer's personnel is changing all the time, they get treated like rubbish buy their own management and the results are bad quality, lack of motivation and never ending levels of miscommunication.

pros:

* Vast majority of people are friendly and willing to help
* Global firm, with regular interaction to all corners of the world
cons:
* London is no longer seen as a growth site for back office functions such as Technology, thus attrition is high and back-fill is usually elsewhere in the globe
* Poor pay compared to market rates
* Limited scope for career progression

review_title: It is a job with a well known company during an economic decline.
job_title: Business Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Well known company worldwide with excellent benefits.

The fact is, banking is the plague, and the requirements to keep your job are not feasible. it may not be fair to completely blame JUST Citibank for this, as I think it is industry wide.

review_title: Citi's management team lacks vision and understanding of customer's need.
job_title: Program Manager in Long Island City, NY
pros: The employees at Citi are intelligent and hard working.

pros:
fantastic people (mostly)
global - opportunities to work abroad
fast, paced dynamic environment
infrastructure, tech, and support are light years beyond competitors

stock price hasn't moved
fair degree of nepotism and bureaucratic behavior
mgmt afraid to think outside the box

review_title: The working conditions just getting worse and worse
pros:
At least you get paid monthly, and it is (or was) a respectable big multinational banking group.
They used to offer new recruits enough training and couching about products and services they offered.
cons: Lots of office politics, promotions are based on skill level of been a boss pleaser or simply a bottom kisser. And the worst part of it is that they don't care about clients, they are selling products that maybe not suitable to clients, but failed to mention about risk involved.

job_title: Vice President Global Mobile Internet Marketing in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Benefits, Flexible work schedule, Vacation time
cons:
Old School, overly rigid, 200 year old company and it acts like it.
Focus is on Credit Cards and profit. 
Power Structure - you are allowed to talk laterally w/those in your employment grade but you cannot approach management 1 - 2 levels up w/ideas; everything must be filtered by your immediate manager whether they are on your side or not.
Very much an 'insider' company w/waiting for people to leave before you can move up the chain.
MANY people work 6 or more years in a position before being promoted and often promotion does NOT include a raise in salary.

review_title: Working for Citibank has been a Learning Experience
pros: Because of the size of the company there are tons of opportunities to grow, not necessarily in your same department, but definitely outside it. Benefits are ok and salaries are ok as well. Diversity is at the core of Citibank, I had never worked for a company more diverse than Citi.
cons: Here is hard to compare apples with apples when it comes to job openings. You could have two accountants, same title and same responsibilities same location, but because they work in different departments within Citi, the pay difference could be unbelievable. Make sure to get into the right department. Benefits are good but expensive ($300-$400 bi-weekly for health insurance in Florida is expensive).

review_title: Good exposure to a lot of departments/functions within the business, decent pay.
pros: Career advancement is possible however it is up to you, you obviously have to prove yourself...AND have a supportive manager.  Granted there are a lot of great managers however there are some that do not belong.  Your experience here will look great on a resume if you don't look to stay long term.
cons: Career growth is limited within Operations (one can only go so far) so look around within the business after putting in your time...pay is "decent" however one will only receive a significant raise if they are well liked/needed and threaten to leave OR if one leaves altogether for over a year and then returns.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Kansas City, MO
pros:

Great vacation allotment
Hours
Exposure to different areas of the business 
Being a business owner from A to Z
Ability to create own processes and have them approved by risk, compliance and legal. 
Ability to work with all levels of management across the business and learn from them.
cons:
Communication from the top down needs to be clearer and more consistent 
Ability to break down silos has to be easier
Right size staffing
Goals need to make sense
Upper management needs to be more open to suggestions and to try new things

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, San Jose
pros: Great Facilities Infrastructure - In general good global tools and processes - Interesting Global Strategies and Vision - Good pay if you negotiate upfront and can sell yourself - Global company - Work from home benefit

job_title: Licensed Associate (Citigold) in San Antonio, TX

co-workers were fun to be around

Management keeps increasing standards and requirements without due consideration of time on calls.

pros: Great place to work if you want to learn fast and face challenges. Company puts a lot of emphasis on diversity. Internal mobility also a great thing, even moving to different countries or functions.
cons: difficult to say, depends on the division you are in, i always had the luck to find good and respectable people and work with them for years, maybe everyone is like that at Citi.

pros: Great Name on your Resume. Global Bank, good online banking. Variety of financial products for your clients. You can serve domestic and international clients as well.
cons: Early 90's technology, Micromanagement does not let you produce. Citi does not care about their employees life, they just care about numbers and Senior Management. Does not have a clear direction of where they go. Managers have favoritism. Citi's procedures are similar to small and cheap Credit Unions. Citi systems work against the employee always. They made a morning meeting where they says the same thing all days, if you made good sales or receive a good survey you're Awesome if not you're a piece of... You know. Considering that Citi is US third biggest bank don't expect that your professional experience will be at state of the art level.

job_title: Homeowner Support Specialist in Irving, TX

This actually is also a good thing as it keeps the company abreast with the industry, however from an employee standpoint it always felt that as soon as we got one thing going well, they would change the process. Also I worked for Citi auto and Citi mortgage, both jobs ended after 3 years. There was a package paid but I'm not unemployed again.

pros:

pros: The banking title for positions sounds great during the interviewing process.

pros: Some company truly lives on the values . Citi never sleep and truly it wont let you sleep . job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Mérida, Yucatán

A global experience.

pros: Was able to work from home for most of my 10 years. Thanks to the never-ending layoffs, was able to attain a large number of different skills.

job_title: Senior Vice President  in New York, NY
pros:
- Global reach. Citi's size creates specializaed functions that enables you to develope skills that are critical to the function.

- In recent years, a very fluid organization.

review_title: badly organized group of talented people

review_title: Learnt a lot, but too many layers of management and conflicting egos led to a lack of clear direction and strategy.

job_title: Corporate Banking Analyst in London, England
pros: The work was, for the most part, interesting. My team were generally welcoming and supportive, I also really enjoyed the analyst training program on offer and learnt a huge amount in my time there, from excel modelling to credit analysis. Citi offers opportunities to relocate to other locations or partake in secondments and rotations in different product teams; resulting in a well-rounded appreciation for the capabilities and services offered by such a global bank. We had a limited amount of team events, and a function-wide Christmas and Summer party - all of which were fairly enjoyable. Salary and bonus are good and in line with the hours that are expected. Citi prides itself on inclusivity and diversity, and I definitely saw and felt these values at play. It was incredible to work with such a diverse bunch of people from all over the globe - finance in London can typically be dominated to the male, pale and stale brigade, but this definitely wasn't my experience of Citi.
cons: Corporate banking is a lifestyle choice. This should be made glaringly obvious upon application.  The hours are long - expect to finish at 9pm on average, increasing to around midnight during crunch times, and roughly 2 Sundays per month - and there is a fair amount of pressure. The nature of the job essentially means you are permanently 'on call', so expect to check emails during holidays and weekends, and expect that you could be asked to come into work at the drop of a hat - I had colleagues who had to reschedule holidays and I cancelled many of my own weekend plans to work on last minute deals. This can take a toll on your mental and physical health, so make sure you are mentally prepared for these hours before you apply. A culture of 'face time' also still exists, which can be quite frustrating from time to time. Internal credit systems were cumbersome, slow and generally very boring and time-consuming to work with; flicking between PDF risk guides, antiquated web-based platforms and excel templates prone to glitches - the whole credit infrastructure could do with a well needed makeover.
