pros: It is a great place to work.  It will provide opportunities for a successful career to anyone with the desire and drive to do so.  A vast global network with numerous opportunities, always willing to provide those that want it with assistance to grow professionally.
cons: Can be political at times, but this will depend on who your boss and peers are.

pros: Steady company. Credit Risk, Yield Book, Investment Research and Finance are decent groups to join. The management teams there are strong and the managers act in a professional manner.
cons:
Financial Planning & Analysis has extremely unprofessional management. The department manager is highly unethical. Avoid this group. 
The business model is to work people are hard as you can and get as much of out them for as little as you can. This may not sound bad but you have people working 60 hours a week for 35k a year. Burn out is extremely high.
The Buffalo site is a "Center of Excellence." The other COEs at Citi are located in 2nd and 3rd world countries dubbed low cost centers. Buffalo is the US version of these other COEs. Upward movement is limited.

pros: I have a job for two years and during the first nine months we received a monthly bonus.  After that, they were cut out.
cons: Loved what I did and meet goals.  Number two producer in section, but when they needed to downsize, other team members under to meet goals, or come to work remained on the team and I was let go.

job_title: Senior Vice President in Wilmington, DE
pros: Good company if you want to rebuild things. So many broken issues and process still today. Salary good, senior mgmt has a vision just not executing at well as it should be.
cons: Still operates in silos. No coordination and working together between groups. Still has legacy culture where things are "always done this way" in certain areas.

review_title: Good for short term, but don't get stuck!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Greensboro, NC
pros: Decent pay, good benefits and paid time off, nice annual appreciation day  fitness center and showers, safe campus, cool co-workers, good 401k.
cons: Extreme micro-management, unrealistic goals, little power to help customers, system upgrades usually make things worse, CEO makes over 17 million , but you're in trouble if you use bathroom during shift, idiotic customers who can't read or understand basic math, never ending shifts that make 8 hours seem like 3 days.  A job that is mentally and emotionally damaging and requires constant sitting.

pros: I have no complains about any of my experience there. Manager was always helpful, let me decide on what project I wanted to work on, floor mates helped me if I was ever stuck or asked them from a problem, and the list goes on.
cons: I don't think I have any cons but if I was to mention one it would be the time taken the first two weeks to set everything up. This length could have been shorter, but rest of the internship made up for the lost two weeks!

review_title: A bit big for its own good.
pros: Global network means lots of opportunity to relocate and try different teams. There are smart people in the organisation if you look but you won't be stumbling over them. Very good people are generally recognised but an awful lot of average gets swept up the ladder too.
cons: Size makes it very process heavy.  Too many people promoted by reaching certain age/weight rather than on merit. Very US centric in outlook. Top heavy.

pros: Citi gives the reps that wish to move up a chance to do so. You can almost always move to other departments as well. You will also work with a wide range of people. I didn't mind leaving Citi as much as I did the people i worked with.
cons: The C in Citi stands for change. Depending on the department that you work for, most policies and procedures will change. Make sure that you pay attention to your emails and if your boss and CA are on top of their game they should let you know most of the updates.

review_title: no opportunities for growth if you start out in the call center
pros: Co-Workers in the same position were amazing. This is one of those positions where you hate the job but love your co-workers.
cons: Stressful, unreasonable expectations, showed the company had no heart, and company wanted you to do their dirty work. Pay was horrible but the benefits were great.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
Large Global Company - experience of large scale global project opportunities.
Good facilities and wide range of work within Investment Banking.
Salary and benefits as you would expect of such a company.
cons:
process improvement / projects hindered by red tape.
Only investment banking business , so scope of project ventures limited.
Project work and team allocation driven by budget and you could find yourself in a team, with reduced budget and at risk.

review_title: Monkey Work in a big bank
job_title: Asset Servicing Analyst in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Mobility. Central location. There is good networking events held which offer the ability to move internally instead of moving outside the company.
cons: Excessive overtime expected. Weak management. I would say you should identify if a role is 'processing based' ind if so recognize that you will be used to work and have to fight for renumeration.

job_title: Data Quality Senior Manager in Tampa, FL
pros: Great benefits, good pay, onsite gym and cafeteria. Decent work life balance.
cons: In the Chief Data Office there are many incompetent managers. The data Quality Controls lead is so afraid of the need Chief Data officer finding out how little value she adds that she will kill process improvements or process overhauls so that they don't find out what a disconnected and inefficient process she has set up.  The morale is terrible and you only advance if you are a favorite and not based on actual skills / accomplishments.

review_title: Look elsewhere for a satisfying postion.
pros: The benefits and flex time -- the management for the most part cares about the people, however, the communication throughout Citi is very archaic.
cons: Very little chance of advancement and we are not seeing much of Pandit throughout all this turmoil.  Where is the leadership? I believe that there are those that want to see the company survive and it will, but a lot of us feel there is a lack of true leadership in this company.  We need someone strong. Vikram is not the man, or to date has not shown this to be.

review_title: Citigroup - Once a great company, today in shambles
pros: A truly global corporation and you will probably work with some of the best people in the industry. Used to be an innovator in the industry, though that is no longer the case.
cons: Limited career advancement potential, lot of bureaucracy and internal politics. It operates as a conglomorate of companies instead of a single corporation ofcussed on a common set of goals and objectives.

review_title: Work for citi if only temporary and for the money
pros: It's largely recognized as one of the biggest worst performing banks. it is international and has a global reach. its a good place for mediocre people who like getting comfortable with there job.
cons: CIti is the worst bank of the top 5 big banks by market value. it is managed terribly and management in the branch level is mostly not well trained. too much need and push to extreme goals of selling bad products.

review_title: Good company to work for, with very good opportunities, but sometime daunted by its own internal political problems.
pros: Big company with a number of internal opportunity; also a company able to trade in large sizes and therefore with the possibility to trade any type of instrument. Mostly friendly attitude and balanced life/work environment.
cons:
A company currently in search of directions, and unclear who is steering it (whether the US government or the CEO). 

A lot of red tapes and inefficient comunication between the business and the infinitely many IT (sub)systems.

review_title: Glass ceiling if you stay in one position without applying for another within 2 years
pros: Citi medical/vacation benefits, 401(k) match @ 6%
cons: Flexible schedule going away, systems nightmare, departmental communication, salary, bonus requirements, paperwork impact time period

review_title: A good place to gain experience and learn how to manage at high level
job_title: Manager Unit Head in Kuala Lumpur
pros: Good working environment and best place to network with successful people
cons: Too much work, a lot of multitasking,  long hours, too many red tapes.

review_title: Not a great company for technology - (Software Development)
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, competitive salary, room for growth. I worked for a smaller company that Citi bought. We had some great teams, great people to work with. Reasonably flexible work hours.
cons:
Over time, Citi pretty much destroyed the company that they had bought. The teams were broken up according to business needs. There would no longer be common architecture among businesses. Most new and challenging development is being outsourced to India. Most new hires were either Indian or Chinese. Citi took US bailout money and then gave most new technology jobs to non-citizens.
No job security. Poor bonuses.

review_title: great benefits with a leading global financial service
pros: I was very fortunate to have worked for Citi. For almost 8 years, I had learned and grown my career and improved financial service skills, and mortgage servicing experience.
cons: In a big company, all training modules are web-based and are quite overwhelming. Such training formats are challenges and you don't have a luxury of classroom settings where you can interact and ask questions with trainers.

review_title: Good company to work for, heading down the right path
job_title: Architect Senior Specialist in Sioux Falls, SD
pros:
I've been with Citi for 8 years coming in at their high and experiencing the crash in 2008. The constants during that time have been:

- Great benefits
- Many opportunities for advancement
- Retain and compensate top talent
- Focus on innovation and becoming the leading digital bank
cons:
- The swirl of senior management (CEO on down) over the last decade has led to several different visions that never had the opportunity to come to fruition. Corbat seems to have the correct vision and has aligned senior management to execute in unison. 

- A lot of red tape which is to be expected in a company of this size.

review_title: Citi private equity services is the worst place I've ever worked!!!  Avoid this place at all costs
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Pretty much none. If you like seeing good people treated like dirt for terrible pay, working on holidays, sexual harassment...work here.  Bonus?  Only if you do "favors".
cons: Al blanco who is the COO is one of the worst people.  Abusing his employees and harassing them is a daily Occurance.   Good luck if you're a woman here.  40% of the staff has left in one year alone.  Have kids?   Say goodbye to them.   Management are either sociopaths or weaklings.

pros: Lots of different activies and responsibiities. Sometimes corporate mandates were really unnecessary for our local area but they did not take too much time. Great place to learn new skills with a good training program.
cons: Too many reports and too many corporate meetings. They got in the way of doing real work. Mgmt tried to help and keep these to a minimum so overall it was not too bad.

job_title: Strategic Sourcing Manager in San Jose, San Jose
pros: The benefits they have are really good, as a former employee the compensation plan was really good. For the time I worked there I had a great work environment and the opportunities to succeed where really good.
cons: They need to work a little bit more about people behavior and how to deal with some troubles between coworkers. Communication is not always effective and can develop a huge wall between some important relations.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Internationally recognized financial organization with an array of products and services.
cons: Training experience is sub par. The time spent in a branch isn't beneficial, so for those who wish to truly develop or enhance their banking career should avoid this organization by all costs. The internal shenanigans that occurs are not worthy of your precious time or effort. The organization provides high quality services to the clients but are extremely limited when it comes to developing their employees. The disparity of banking knowledge and professionalism is obvious upon the first day of working alongside "seasoned" Citi employees. I worked at a several different locations and interacted with employees nationwide; so on a national scale the quality of the team that I encountered was saddening. Do yourself a favor, work somewhere else.

pros: Great opportunities for early and mid-career, proven performers who seek them.  A great global culture.  Great people.  Never a need to suffer from boredom!  Great focus on hiring and growing talent (in the past couple of years).  Good corporate focus on women and developing their talent as executives.
cons: Can be very political.  Meritocracy gets watered down due to bell-curve ratings within individual groups and functions.  The rating/ranking system doesn't encourage or reward high-performing teams.  Holding the "corporate line" is rewarded more than hard results sometimes.

pros: The pay is good, the benefits are ok (insurance, like everywhere else, is prohibitively expensive) and other benefits are competitive.
cons: Silos exist from department to department and, along with the lack of any accountability, leads to an inability to successfully navigate the bureaucracy to actually accomplish anything. If you're coming to Citi from the outside, stay away.. The culture is such that you won't be accepted and you won't be given the resources to succeed.

pros: Good benefits, pension, BUPA, maternity and internal gym. Great company culture, good for working mums.A little behind on effective processes/systems. However have made progression in the 9years I have been working at Citi
cons: Hard work is not always recognised and long hours expected at times. Promotion/ progression don't always go to the people who deserve it. Clear variation of pay within the same team and internal pay increases are not great. Training of new staff is not structured.

job_title: Applications Development Intermediate Programmer Analyst in London, England
pros: A decent salary, experience working in a large financial institution, and a not too pressured working environment are all good reasons to work for Citi.  There are also good career options with internal mobility.
cons: The technology is not always the latest and greatest; there are some exceptions and teams doing really good work, but there are also some legacy systems.  In such a large company it is also possible for mediocracy to survive.

pros:
- Global Reach
- Good learning experience working on financial projects
- Good exposure to many tech and skilled people
- A good name for you to get another job in the financial industry
cons:
- Short-sighted. Everyone just cares about the end of year bonus and getting promoted so they can get another job in the financial industry
- They have an army of incompetent managers. 
- Consistent management turnover. New directions every quarter.
- Bureaucratic, politically charged environment, highly-regulated institution. It can be challenging to get things approved.
- Bad coffee
- HR practically unavailable and inoperative, overloaded with paperwork, policies, and regulations,
- Working in a global environment, you have to wake up late for meetings.

review_title: I would not suggest anybody to be here in at least AML.
job_title: AML Compliance Analyst in Warsaw, Masovia
pros: Big Name in MNC but fact that AML department is not so good and filled with politics.
cons:
So much deep and pathetic Politics,
Talk about Multi Culture but the fact is that they do not let you grow. 
Not a good money compare to other players in market,
Illogical Policies that keeps you stressed.
Majority Manger's are so much filled with ego and proud.

pros: It is a call center job, collections specialist. It’s a bit tough to get used to being on the phones 8 hours a day, however the company is great. The starting pay is almost twice the minimum wage in my area, benefits start from day one AND are better than any company I’ve ever worked for. From bonuses that are easily obtained, medical, dental, paid vacation & sick time, FMLA, short term disability, paid maternity AND paternity time....it’s wonderful. Constant promotion opportunities.
cons: Being on the phones, and lately changing managers every 2 months...whom all have different requirements that can make you fail Qualities.

review_title: Great People, Not So Good Company
pros: Definitely the people. I enjoy working with them and being around them in general. It's a culture where everyone gets along with each other and the senior folks definitely try to take care of the new folks. During my internship, everyone was very supportive and understanding. I was invited to go back but decided to look at other options due to the state of our economy.
cons: It is a company that is very unstable at the point. The lack of job security has led to an outflow of talent. The company has struggled recently due to the economic crisis and I hope for the best for everyone there.

pros: Citis rotational program offers excellent flexibility, great work life balance. I really feel as through I can gain whatever skills and experience I need during the program. Its a highly respected program with in the organization and I also get a sense that graduates of the program do excel if they focus.
cons: Like working at any other global bank, there is too much red tape. You need to obtain approvals for many minute details and overall accountability through out the organization is low. If you have an overall mentality of "lets get things done" it can be difficult.

review_title: Best part of working at Citi  - the people.
job_title: Human Resources Data Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Throughout my time at Citi, I've worked with very talented and genuinely nice people. There are plenty of opportunities for employees to develop their careers. The salaries are competitive and the benefits are great.
cons: There are days where you will have to put in long hours. In HR, there isn't really a training program, you pretty much learn on the fly and have to trust that the person walking you through the process knows what s/he is talking about. Because it's such a large organization, sometimes it's difficult to navigate through it and there can be a lot of bureaucracy involved.

review_title: *NOT WORTH* You will make a lot of money, for a short time, BUT you will want to eat a bullet before the end.
job_title: Mortgage Consultant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Only one Pro. You make a lot of money. The next best benefit is being able to put Citi on your resume when you leave.
cons: Everything else. Soul grinding, heavy rules & regulations. Absolutely everything is numbers driven, no consideration is given for personal behavior. How's his numbers? Bad=Fired, Good=Keep. From the moment you walk in the door, they are trying their best to get you fired (more money and job security for them). To survive here, for even a short amount of time, you have no choice but to become a specialist in all the CYA internal rules, regulations & procedures. Even if you spend your entire day trying to CYA they will eventually find some obscure rule to force you out.

pros: There are a lot of bright people in the company and people who want to do a good job.  Excellent benefits.
cons: There is also a massive amount of dysfunctional behavior.  Relentless cost cutting yet tons of highly paid staff, who add virtually no value and in some cases detract value, because of the burden they place on others.  Large fiefdoms are tolerated.  Work ethic, at least in Dallas is weak.  An incredible number of rude people in terms of interpersonal skills, being late for meetings, contempt for people of lesser titles.

review_title: One of the worst companies one could ever encounter
pros: The best reason to work here would be the money if you were paid right.  If you have connections and can get into the in crowd, you can make a lot of money.
cons: If you are not in the right "crowd", you will run into a wall very quickly.  Management is cut throat and very protective of the lofty roles that they don't deserve but are holding on to at all costs.  They were willing to see the company go down in flames rather than cut fat at the highest level.

job_title: THD Commercial Revolving Customer Service in Irving, TX
pros: There are absolutely none for this department.
cons:
Pay and Incentives are not competitive with other institutions.

Statistics are a top priority.

There is an overabundance of red tape and compliance issues.

There are a lot of Legacy computer systems and programs agents use are not updated. The Call Center that is not properly maintained as well as outdated equipment.

Career growth is unclear though possible.

When things go wrong with products or a store associate charges incorrect amount to clients accounts the process for a correction to be made is a long and  arduous one.

You get 2 breaks that are 15 minutes and  30 minute lunch.

Overall if anyone with Call Center experience may want to explore other avenues for other companies or other departments.

pros: Strong company. Good benefits. Colleagues are great to work with.
cons: Technology is very outdated. Hundreds of workarounds via several layers of systems to complete your job. Broken promises of individual career development with the excuse of a "hiring freeze". Approximately 50% understaffed in the mortgage department. Capacity is a major issue that doesn't seem to light a bulb for leaders. New leadership every 6 months and of course they come with their new set of ideas that just make things worse. In the works of "defining roles", leaders decided that every responsibility that wasn't attached to a role should be the Processor's responsibility.

pros:
Lots of different countries... which is a good thing if you want to have a very international career.  Otherwise, it just makes things hard to manage from the top.

Biggest upside is the low expectations of people around you, it's easy to astound them.
cons: Truly uncreative environment.  Competitive and political, but in a vicious unproductive way unlike other FIs where competition spurs excellence and a desire to thrive.

job_title: Market Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Nice amount of paid-time off, holidays, etc.  Can definitely learn a lot about marketing, banking and finance.  Most people are nice.  Let you work at home 1-2 days/week.
cons: Workload is too heavy.  A lot of favoritism.  Hard to maintain work/life balance.  A lot of managers looking to move themselves ahead without consideration of their subordinates.

pros: it is a great company to work for. benefits or ok. you would be lucky to work from home. you are able to focus and get work done
cons: as long as you keep work at work and personal very quiet then you should be ok. it can get very unprofessional if you allow your personal at work. this is based on all the issues that I have seen through co workers. I kept my personal to myself and was one of the only to maintain a job until the major layoff. communication can be off. GET EVERYTHING IN WRITING!

pros:

Great bonuses

Easy systems to work with
No stress for me atleast
cons: I got nothing negative to say other than keep the branches here. People really love this bank and its culture. Stop closing branches and losing valuable customers. You will love woeking here, especially if you have a great manager. Its like a family!

job_title: Relationship Banker in New York, NY
pros: Citigroup incentive plan is great in ways that there are many ways to make money. cons: With constant change  in Citibank policy and procedures, and regulations, its hard to see and make changes on day to day operations. Rules may be to vague , or rules may not be clear when processing truncations at the bank. this can lead to concerns with higher ups, and management.

review_title: Always have a back up plan
job_title: Liaison, Claims Specialist in Dallas, TX

cons: the company lays off a lot so I am always wondering if my name will be on the next list because the layoffs are not seniority based or performance or attendance related.

pros: As part of the Analytics Information Management (AIM), you get an opportunity to work with some diverse data across markets from the Asia-Pacific, EMEA and the North America region.

pros:
Money

Health care & pension

Free Cycling changing rooms with showers.

WFH options.

review_title: How not to make your employees feel like a "little fish in a large pond"
job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Baltimore, MD
pros: There are a lot of opportunities to work in different areas of the company and learn new skills due to the large size and scale of Citigroup.
cons: Due to the large size and complexity of the organization, it is hard to feel like you matter to senior management.  Often times, it is difficult to get changes and improvements made due to the substantial layers of management and the amount of bureacracy involved within the company.

job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Prestige - that's about it...for now. Citi is weathering this financial storm in a mediocre manner. If it does not improve soon it will be another Lehman Brothers. Next year's analyst class is going to have a rough time because the Ops work is BORING AS ANYTHING. I want to get the hell out of here.
cons: The culture is very disconnected, it is hard to make relations and senior management is unapproachable. ALso, exit opps are not great as well.

review_title: Good place to start as a FA but there is an image problem currently
pros: Freedom and flexibility to do the right thing for your client. There is no pressure to recommend products that are not in the best interest of your client. You are free to build your business the way you want.
cons: It takes a lot of work to build your practice to the point of it being self-sustaining.

review_title: A good place to work for tough people who can stand a high frustration level
job_title: Assistant Vice President in London, England
pros: Depending for what department and what organisation within Citi you are working, it is a good place to work. Compensation packages have been above banking average, company offers excellent internal and external training possibilities for beginners and skilled staff as well, strong commitment to diversity, interesting travel possibilities if working for a global or regional organisation, good possibility to learn how a world wide operating enterprise is organised and working, good place to learn how to read and listen "between the lines", good place to learn the importency of politics and that being in the right "Club" will help to survive, good place to learn something about the cultural differences of how some work task are understood and worked.
cons: To much to write here. Citi has a horrifying week Senior Management, with no Leadership, No truth, No trust anymore. Speaking about my experiences, to much and permanent reorganisations, producing confusion and frustration for staff and customers. If you join Citi in EMEA you have to know the right people, and being located in London is as well a big advantage for your career. Anyway, if you do not belong to the right "Club" you will never be promoted at all, regardless of your location or if you are working you ass off. Promotions are usually based on politics not on skills or performance. As a result you will find many nope heads within leading positions only because they belong to the right inner circle, to the right "Club". To many managers listen to the wrong people and wasting the companies money with ridiculous strategic decisions based on wrong assumptions given by clueless nope heads. You will find a world full of fear, where the few good people left have to be very quite to avoid to get there heads cut off in the next "right placement" round. High skilled people and teams, capable to manage issues quick and efficient have been fired. Their core knowledge is wasted and gone, their responsibilities have been moved to so called "low cost" locations. As a result, customer dissatisfaction has been increased, service levels have gone down. If you don't care about the company you work for, if you could talk the talk, if you like to play dirty political games, if you already know the right people to avoid a "right placement", Welcome to join the madhouse !. But if pointless processes, permanent reorganisations and obviously wrong strategic decisions might frustrate you easily, if you like to work customer orientated, quick and efficient, if you easily might loose you politeness on phone, because you have to talk again with a clueless peanuts paid "low cost" location monkey, then stay out of Citi, this is not the right place for you.

review_title: If you can , avoid Citi at any cost
pros: Citi offers its employees a very good benefits, the 401 k matches you contribution 1 $ to 1 $ .
cons: Citi will work you to death, Citi never sleeps and you will too. Burocracy is literaly whats killing them, you may spend most of your day making sure that you follow the procedures, it leave no time for actual work. Budget cuts everywhere, no coffee, no caps nothing left but more work. NO bonuses, no rises this year, most likely next year too.

pros: Although I worked for outside of United States, many HR recruiters took a look my resume because Citigroup is a really big name. This company will open the door for the another great opportunity.
cons: HR really doesn't have any power, so this causes unfairness between departments in the company.  Now, I moved on to different industry and realized that the Citigroup culture was too aggressive.

pros: The global exposure Citibank has provides many opportunities and a wide network.  You will have the chance to work with many exceptional people.
cons: Citi has a habit of 'playing favorites'. Although there are many exceptional people at Citi, there are many who are not there on their own merits, and will continue to get promoted and be protected for all the wrong reasons.  Citi is not very good at rewarding on merit alone.

pros: Good atmosphere in general, you can get into a good group and have a great social life. When you joing the company there is a feeling that youv'e signed up to something great.
cons: Work life is not great, long hours and pay package is pathetic. Very very political. Hard work doesn't pay at all. It seems like the only way to be successful in the company is saying the right thing at the right time. Getting a promotion is next to impossible unless you are always on the right side of management. You get away with doing nothing and staying long hours and getting rewarded for it.

pros:
- Typical bulge bracket environment

- The resources are out there.....

.... It is just very difficult to track them down..

- Ahhhh- technology, it's rubbish. Lead out of the US, who appear to care very little about their EU counterparts

review_title: One of the worst professional experiences of my life
pros: Still maintains brand recognition, good facilities and infrastructure (albeit not as good as JP Morgan Chase), very friendly co-workers, great opportunities to work remotely if one were so inclined.
cons: Dishonest middle managers, poor understanding of the advantages of using technology, implied threats of termination used to "motivate" employees into working 80 hours a week (salaried/no OT), very poor consideration towards employees that are high achievers/performers vis-a-vis rewarding performance with more work without the additional acknowledgement of added responsibility/title/salary, mostly ambiguous goals/unclear strategy, overall very poor morale, very poor work/life balance, and generally just not a good environment to start or advance your career in.

review_title: Too much new "middle-management" trying to prove itself resulting in MAJOR Micro-management.
pros: Citi hires quality people at branch level. Has a good training program. Doesn't have long/Sunday hours. New, innovative products.
cons: MICRO-MANAGEMENT from Division managers on down resulting in higher than ever turnover. Very Low morale in the branches.  Too many changes. Tell us to "build relationships" then want numbers-numbers-numbers. Constant PRESSURE to produce. Never enough.

pros: Bank has well known name and brand
cons: Benefits are not the best, every year the varibale compensation capacity is cut, corporate culture promotes unethical behavior even though they say it does not, managers do whatever they want-do not lead by example, upper management is always the rejects from other large banks, they do not value talent, rather hire from outside instead of promote from within, most of the time.

job_title: Applications Development Senior Manager in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Employees are professional, Smart and team oriented. Training is encouraged and a wide range of courses are available.
cons: The morale is poor. people go about doing their jobs best they can but the prospect of layoffs is constantly hanging over their heads. Too much focus on cost cutting. There is constant focus on moving people and jobs to low cost locations, reducing operating budgets, outsourcing to vendors.  They have recently resorted to sharing workstation space to reduce office space and confiscated Blackberrys.

pros: You'll have great opportunities after you leave and some opportunities to advance if you stay. Work can be intense but interesting. You are able to have a decent amount of exposure to senior people, although a lot of that might end up happening when you are being scolded.
cons: Every director thinks their work is the most important and Citi would crumble and fall without them, so managing egos is a skill everyone will gain. Hours can be long but that is expected, and everyone is very siloed into their role.

pros: Nice work location, plenty of parking. I tendered my resignation as soon as I found a better job.

review_title: Everything is done with a shoestring budget, also potential unpaid work during unsociable hours
job_title: IT Graduate Associate in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Work hours are totally flexible and it's possible for most developers to work from home. Unlimited hot beverages are available and there are good efforts in organising social events. Also, there is an enormous library of online training available and some on-site training also. The 'Citi collaborate' work social networking tool is also an excellent source of resources and a great way to network with people outside your department - and so it's easy to network with people working with similar technologies or with similar interests. There are many clubs/societies organised within Citi covering a wide spectrum of interests and sports. Citi donates 1 day of every employees time to take part in a volunteering activity within the community. Desks are big enough and chairs are suitable.
cons: Everything is done with a minimum of resources. Teams are running complex applications without proper processes and methodologies. The business just doesn't seem to understand what is actually needed to make software. Teams don't have proper build or test processes, and many developers don't even have some of the most basic developer tools and hardware. Most of the developer machines are very low-spec, and can be painfully slow when dealing with some development work. Also, my department seems to have a gigantic budget shortfall, and they've dealt with this by forcefully relocating people to cheaper locations and by getting rid of many contractors (and not replacing them). Additionally, many developers have to work unsociable hours for weekend releases, and they are not paid for their troubles, and even getting the time off in lieu wasn't easy. Also, making requests for basic software, hardware and configurations is a painful and extremely slow process. I don't see any of these things improving any time soon. It's actually difficult to be productive at Citi, there are many obstacles, and not just because of strict banking regulations. Also, there is little cohesion within the department.

review_title: Great people, excellent work environment, tremendous learning opportunities
pros: I have been working for Citi for more than three years. I really like the people, my job and the working conditions. The benefits, cafeteria and learning opportunities are excellent. Work life balance is good. The managers really listen to me and provide feedback. If you are proactive then you are at the right place. Be open minded and listen to suggestions and look for the opportunities.
cons: Tons of emails, newsletters, updates. It is a huge, global company and so many things happening here. Once in a while I found it very difficult to follow all those changes.

job_title: Analyst in Long Island City, NY
pros: You can gain global experience. The company is on a path of restoring its good reputation producing solid results and repositioning to a better operating model. You have the opportunity to communicate people on the global scheme and build a network.
cons: High turnover due to cost cutting, subpar compensation and uninspiring work environment. While senior leaders are great, some of the lower level directors and SVPs are incompetent and do not foster a great mentorship culture. Talent and hard work is recognized in certain groups, however it is not rewarded financially. Uneven distribution of work within groups.

pros: Underwriting is very liberal and underwriting managers are very easy to talk to.  Will go through scenarios and help when needed.  A lot of other banks have "hours" for when you can contact underwriters and these ops people are happy to help!
cons: Very conservative as an employer.  Requires lots of work on improving KDS scores but then doesn't do things to help employees do their jobs better.  For example, tellers have to ask clients about their mortgages, finances AND help them with their banking needs.  In order to keep the wait time down for the line, a teller cannot possibly try to sell these products to clients.

review_title: no work life balance, actually, no life at all
pros: office location, decent people (peers), good brand, honesty and integrity of operations
cons: with its global challenges the profitable office/entity needs to "support" those in need, meaning no matter how profitable we are, it doesn't reflect on the increase of capacity and resource, nor on our personal compensation.  1 personnel has to do the jobs of multiples, therefore it's a 9 to 11 - 9AM to 11PM job most of the time.  the team is great, peers are from great schools, decent and honest, but executive team is absolutely disconnected from reality.  they live in bubbles.

review_title: Best for retirement salary and worst for growth
pros: Flexible work from home options, 6% 401k match, good health insurance and paid vacations.With little effort you can keep your current job and have stable retirement salary.
cons:
My review is specific to Global Consumer Bank Organization in Citi and specific to Senior and middle level Management. 
 
Difficult to grow up the food chain, due to lot of politics and internal issues. Lots of different political groups based on regional/racial basis. 
Senior Management is pretty insecure and they will not allow any changes to organization. For any new project everything looks perfect, but when it comes to execution, we fail or take more time to execute than other banks. 
Technology group is pretty retarded in next gen approach; they don't have any consistently on their decisions.
Employees from some locations are insecure, they will not allow a new person to provide better and new ideas, even if project cost increases drastically or is bound to fail.
Hiring standards are worst in the industry, they hire based on recommendations and lobbying
One external client/vendor says "if I want to work with Citi, I have to work with three dozen people instead of three or 4 people".
Agile/Scrum is a big joke,  none of the decisions are made in scrum team, every decision goes back to managers for approval. The work hours estimate for regular waterfall development and new agile/scrum process  are still the same. Senior management does even look or try to understand why we cannot execute projects similar to other companies in industry. Citi GCB is like GM in Automobile sector. All the profits in last five years in GCB are by selling citi holding assets or exiting other countries.  Citi GCB should go through complete overhaul similar to GM

C Level Management had organized many seminars and recommendation from external technical evangelist to internal teams to improve the way Citi works, but these recommendation are never executed or failed to execute.

The only last major accomplishment is executing Costco project on time.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY

There are plenty of opportunities to get promoted or moved to different departments or job functions.
cons: Compensation is not as competitive as other financial institutions. For individuals with similar experience and level of profession, CIti may have lower compensation.

review_title: Good Place to work but has it's downsides as all very large companies do

review_title: Good job and benefits, just not for me

review_title: Relatively new employee wishes Citigroup knew anything about technology.
job_title: Financial Advisor in San Jose, CA
pros: Citigroup is a powerful financial institution with a lot of resources unique to the institution. As a financial advisor, I have access to a lot of in-house resources and tools for my clients that are, as far as I can tell, unique to the industry. They pay fairly well and the overall environment here is not bad, and there is a good deal of comraderie between advisors within the office. Once everything was set up, we've had a good deal of autonomy as to how we run our business within the firm, so in that respect I'm quite satisfied.
cons: Citigroup has more beaurocracy than any company I have ever seen. Anything in my branch can be done relatively quickly, but setting up accounts for interns, making any changes to my workstation, or attempting to do anything that requires outside approval takes forever. My HR director has been working for the firm for almost 20 years and still is confused by the system, not because she is less than competent but because the system makes very little sense. In addition, the firewall and operating system all computers are required to have almost, but not quite, completely cripples my ability to do any work with technology of any kind. There is a fairly good software suite preinstalled on the computer, but any applications that I want to use that haven't gone through the endless Citigroup approval process can't be installed. Upgrading or replacing technology of any kind is also very difficult. In addition, in the recent market Citigroup made some financial mistakes that were extremely costly to my busniess and my clients, so I'm entirely less than happy about that, but some of the other deals I have managed to get for them mostly makes up for some of the recent fiascos.

review_title: Great training ground, though average pay
pros:
* If you can get in here at the beginning of your career, then you will learn a lot as they have some of the best product, marketing, and operational processes along with financial discipline that I have experienced in my career to date.
* As things happen at light-speed at Citi, sideward promotions are done quickly so you can move around the different teams within a business unit quite quickly. Upward promotions are another story (see cons).
cons:
* Unlike other organisations, Citi is extremely tight with expenses. Everything is analysed to death before a decision (normally a "no") is made. I noticed a big pull back around the GFC, and it didn't let up many years thereafter. I believe this stifles innovation and risk taking, and unfortunately I see that Citi has gone from an innovator to a follower.
* Middle management is too focused on protecting their own nests and fighting for the top promotions when they come up from time-to-time.
* The overall culture in the bank is dog-eat-dog -- people are generally so overworked and competitive that they aren't willing nor have the time to help you...and why would they help a competitor for a future promotion that they're going after?!
* The pay is really average compared to the big 2/4 - like I said, really great place to learn but terrible if you want to get financially recognised for your experience.
* Overall, there seems to be a lack of cohesiveness with the strategy of the consumer bank -- do we just focus on the Credit Cards business which is a cash cow, or should we actually become a proper bank and accept deposits and write mortgages? The branch network is orientated towards Asian investors, and sends a mixed message.

review_title: CitiMortgage is a mess all over. Great pay and benefits, but it comes at a cost.

pros: Strong cohesive strategy leading the company in the right direction. Early adopter of technology to facilitate efficiency. Being a long time employee I can really see and feel the positive changes.  The bank feels smaller and more cohesive.

job_title: Senior IT Business Analyst in Jacksonville, FL
pros: A resonably competent, intelligent person will have an easy time at Citi. But you will have to deal with a lot of stupid people, especially in the "management" bureaucracy. And you would do well to remember not to care, no matter how much they try to force you to care, because otherwise you'll be very unhappy caring about stuff that doesn't matter.
cons:
Management constantly tries to overtake your life, applying ridiculous pressure to achieve goals that were assigned by people who have no clue, on timelines that bear no relation to reality. Always push back because there's no punishment; they just want to intimidate you into getting more work out of you for less money. If you accrue overtime, they'll often make you roll it over into another week where you'll work fewer hours, so they don't have to pay overtime rates. Citi is already involved in a class-action lawsuit over that practice, but they keep doing it.
Citi laughably reveres the uninvolved upper management as "the seniors". Title inflation is rampant. A simple team lead/supervisor is labeled Vice President, President or Director.
Employees have good benefits but no work-life balance. Having 5 weeks of paid vacation is useless because you can never take it when you want, only when management says you can. Usually they just tell you to take a week off, with no warning, so you can't plan for anything. Then they still expect you to work on your vacation.
Citi harps on "compliance" and following all sorts of rules, but they often follow only the letter of the rule-- there is a well-established workaround for every rule.
Citi relies heavily on Indian and Pakistani contractors, so women at Citi often suffer from a hostile work environment. If you're Indian/Pakistani, black, lesbian, transgender, or ideally a combination of all of those, you're in a "protected class" at Citi. Everyone else, not so much.
Remember, banking is one of the worst industries to be in (like farming, only with less death and dismemberment). Pay is low, morale is low, opportunity for advancement is low. So in that regard, Citi is typical. There are MUCH better places to work. I work here because it's convenient and I don't have to work hard for the money. But I would not recommend Citi to anyone as a career, or as anything more than a stepping stone to your next job at a different company. "Soul-sucking stupidity" is a good summary of the work environment at Citi.

review_title: I love working for this company
pros: Great retirement matching (100% match up to 6% of your salary); flexible work environment (open seating, can work from home); very affordable health insurance (about $100 a month for myself - company covers over 80% of the yearly cost); paid parental leave (4 months fully paid for mothers, 2 months for fathers + 4.5 months unpaid job-protected leave); $3000 adoption assistance; subsidized childcare up to 20 days per year per child; up to $5,250 yearly tuition reimbursement for college courses; 1 paid day off per year to volunteer in the community; 3.5 weeks off starting for salaried employees (2.5 starting for hourly workers) up to 5.5 weeks off for senior level employees; free access to Udemy and Degreed for online courses on many topics; 10 paid holidays per year; up to $300/yr in gift cards for working out/being healthy; free clinic/M.D.s on most campuses (they will treat you/give you most prescriptions for free); free talk therapy/counseling on site during work hours; welcoming community in the office with lots of generations working in the workplace/lots of diversity; good feedback (bi-yearly reviews from your manager); great technology to foster communication for global teams - most calls are over video and teams usually have team members across the globe; great opportunity for advancement; very open to location changes & wanting to get experience at different offices, even internationally (relocation packages based on distance you are moving)
cons: Your day-to-day work experience really comes down to your direct manager or supervisor.  Some managers don't mind you working from home every day or just want you to get your work done for the week and don't care when you do it.  Others expect you to be in the office from 8-5 every single day regardless of whether you have work to do.  More consistency would be nice, but it's a large company so I realize these differences are somewhat unavoidable.

review_title: It all depends on the division.
pros:
Pay comparable to other banks (more beneficial at the junior level... ie raise and bonus increases)
Benefits, people, culture - all AMAZING
Global industry/consumer risk is well coordinated and well-compensated
RIsk policy/architecture teams are great as well
DEFINITELY a great place to work, but you have to go to the right dvision
cons:
-The risk organization is great, however, there are large disparities between the divisions and the way that they are treated.  If you are working on the risk team supporting the main business side (banking and trading), you are much better off than supporting a smaller division.  (Also note that working in risk policy/architecture is great too) Even within the business side, it is split between two main industries: global industry/consumer (probably the best place to work within risk) and all other financial institutions.  The financial side is run completely differently (sometimes appropriately given the nature of the business), and is often inefficient when it comes to policies and procedures.  As a junior in this division, there is a lot of back and forth.  They aren't used to having juniors ---> resulting in a lack of serious responsibilities and a lot of grunt work.  Because the seniors in the FI group tend not to be as open to other perspectives, there is a lot of back and forth on minor documents resulting in inefficiency.  It's a little better for more senior level people (it's great if you are running a group or division), but the back and forth inefficiencies are still in play. If you're going to do risk, go to the global industries/consumer side on all levels unless you are running a division or subdivision.

- Transferring between businesses is difficult (know EXACTLY what you want to do when you come in).... but in the same business different industry, it is MUCH easier

review_title: Citi is built on bitter employees with the "minimum range pay gets minimum productivity" mentality.
job_title: IT Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Insurance is ok, it gets worse every year.  Most mortgage related positions get monthly bonuses, while IT gets the mushroom cap.  IT hasn't seen a bonus since 2007, raises in IT are 2% (enough to go out to an ok dinner once a month).  Most managers operate on the hospital model, meaning the doctors (managers) get paid well, while the nurses (administrative assistants/leads) do all the work of their managers.
cons: Citi is generally a "Joy Free" zone.  Every URL you go to in the Google Chrome browser is logged, your calls are recorded, your IM conversations are logged and reviewed by legal, this is often a good excuse for "house cleaning" of employees.  If your spouse works for Citi, be suspicious!  Chances are they're out in someones' car in the lot or at Busch Wildlife hooking up, this is a fact, and everyone knows, male or female.  Female employees (usually in the Loss Mit area) have been known to hook up with male co-workers, managers, and even the landscaping crew.  The few long time employees are just hanging on to retirement, lots of those positions (coincidently) are JD'ed (Job Discontinuance) just before retirement...but the good news is those people are let go saving the company money, making the stock price go up (that's all that counts right?), and the work is absorbed by other employees..Job discontinuance means that "job" (work) is no longer required...then why is that work that is no longer required passed on to other employees?  Someday the company will be sued because of this.  The local hospitals comment as soon as you say you work at Citi that the majority of their cardiac patients come from Citi.  All the good IT talent leaves Citi, they always ask why and do nothing to change it.  The answer is low pay.  Employees have complained about outsourcing, Citi responds by bringing people from India (and their families) and puts them up in an extended stay hotel, paying for a rental car, meals, etc (and their families) and calls it "INsourcing"....cute.  When it's time for reviews, you have to stop what you're doing to fill out timely self evaluations (twice a year) where you have to justify your own job, only to be kept on, and receive a terrible excuse for a merit raise once a year.  A $500 raise per year (after taxes) is enough to treat yourself to a single person meal at Outback Steak House once a month...as long as you use a coupon though.  Most mortgage workers will leave under good terms to go to a competitor, only to come back to Citi within 6 months to a year at a higher rate of pay, and repeat this to pad their salary.  Upper management doesn't know who you are or give a tinkers damn, and has the audacity to thank you for your hard work during town hall meetings, and claims they have an open door policy if you have a problem.  I really could go on, sadly there's really little to say in the "pros box".  Outsourcing to India has slowed only because people in Budapest are cheaper.  Outsourcing the the already outsourced, when will it end?  Outsourced workers in India are rude, demanding, and when you can understand their broken and incorrect English, are terrible at what they do.  Even the programmers put out embarrassing bug-ridden code...but good news, the company saved money, and thats what allows the well oiled machine to keep running.

My manager stated she tried escalating the issues however no one above her were even aware of my concern. I talked to a couple of my other female coworkers and they stated the manager pushed for their days off all the time. They will lure you in with all of this vacation time but you will never get to use it. 

They will say there are "advancement opportunities". - Every manager spends at least 10 hours (sometimes 12 and more) a day at work, working crazy hours, once again, they expect the same from you
- Fire people without replacing them and expect the rest of the team to do their work load.

review_title: Play their game... or get out!
job_title: Collections Representative (Private Label) in Albuquerque, NM
pros:
Great people, very friendly place to work. 
Vacation and personal time bank is well above other companies. 
Benefits are great and include short term disability paid at 100% for some time (depending on seniority). 
Some managers allow you to flex your time to take care of personal issues without using your vacation or sick time.
cons:
Working for this call center is like high school, you get promoted for knowing and being friends with managers. Tons of favortism. You can bypass this by applying for a TAP position which is a training program for those wanting to be managers. I believe its a 2 year program. 

Bonus/incentive is iffy. They allow managers to have disgretion if you get your bonus- even if you met all standards and were a top performer. They can take it away for petty things like a disagreement with your manager earlier in the month. 

Citi has an unrealistic expectation of how collectors talk to customers and has a very confusing scoring card for the call. There is no script to go by. You have to ask many many questions about what happened to them financially to get them behind, where are they now financially, and when do they think the situation will change and include dates. Since we call the same customer every 4 days, these same questions have to be asked again, even if we know and can see the answers from the last call. This just upsets customers and makes our job harder.  

Incentive metrics are always changing and getting harder and harder to make. Unachivable at times for many reps.  

Communication is horrible all around. It is very hard to know what is going on within the site. Some reps don't have emails to get communication. Changes to policies happen without notification/training (many times the communication isn't passed to reps). If a change is made and you are not there that day, you may never know of the change. Sometimes these are big changes that will prevent you from passing your calls- thus leading to your bonus being revoked. 

Training is minimal because there is not a active training system to prepair you for real calls. You don't know what you are doing until you have to hit the floor and have to figure it out on your own. Training for calls consists of powerpoint slide shows, not an active training system. You also get to sit and listen to reps but most will not allow you to touch the system because it will effect their stats. Thankfully, reps understand this because they have been there, and are always willing to help out the new hire once they get to the floor.    

Lots of FDCPA violations all around because the auto dialing system doesn't work very well. Making changes to make sure we are in compliance has taken years (3+ at this site).  They are still working on fixing it!!! Changes like this take forever and as a rep I really can not understand why. 

HR (on site) is substandard. They refer you to a 1 800 # for everything and can not explain to you issues about benefits, pay, leave, or anything else for that matter. They are there for hiring, firing, and investigating personel issues. When you work in a call center the last thing you want to do is call another call center. LOL

review_title: Used to be great, but the quality of work that management has done in the past two years is terrible.
pros: Great reputation, great benefits, staff is always great to work with. Definitely have competitive pay and benefit packages, but overall leadership skills are lacking.
cons: Leadership skills are lacking. Management always changing things, giving you the runaround. At least in the Los Angeles area, its very difficult to move up or grow within the company. Not only at my locations, but know of many cases where management preferred to hire from outside the company than within, despite there being many highly qualified people within the company.

review_title: Nothing I'm passionate about, but a solid place to work.
pros: Managers are great and understanding and feedback is always given to help you improve. They don't tolerate slacking or rule breaking and you have to work hard to keep your job secure, which I like. Flexible schedules - managers work with you. In my department at least, praise is definitely given for a good job. Good team environment, they help you to succeed. You may not be passionate about the work you're asked to do, but in my opinion Citi DOES take care of their employees and do hire people who are friendly, caring, and enjoy helping others. Their pay may not be the best, but you get benefits from day 1, overtime is readily available, and you get a lot of time off, as well as bonuses for working nights or on weekends, full meals for working holidays, etc. I think they make up for it.
cons: It is a financial institution, so you constantly have to make decisions that are unfair for the client to benefit the business and some information you are asked to give can be misleading, especially when you are asked to cover up flaws in Citi policy and put the fault on someone else. Many times a client will be impacted due to a bank error and we will do nothing to fix it. We manage risk in my department, so closing accounts and decreasing credit. We don't take the customer's situation into account at all - it's purely numbers, and little sympathy is given. They stress and judge your performance on 'putting the client first' when the work they ask us to do is purely putting the company first. Scoring can sometimes be unrealistic and unfair. You may do a spectacular job, but if you forget to say 1 line your score is dropped automatically. Also, in many departments handle time is more important than quality time spent with the customer, and unrealistic sales goals are implemented which results in a high turnover rate.

job_title: Human Resources in Las Vegas, NV
pros: For such a large company, the communication is very good. I feel like I know what is happening because Vikram Pandit is very transparent about where we stand before earnings reports and big announcements are made.
cons: Sometimes it's hard to tell what your individual impact is to the company's overall progress.

job_title: Vice President in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Flexible hours, good vacation and time off benefits.
cons: Regimented HR comp process so once you are hired in, you are severely limited on any pay increases.No raise allowed for taking a new job that is the same grade and 5-7 per cent max for a 1 level promotion.You have to leave and hire back in at the next level to get any real increase.  Merit increases are 1 or 2 percent max and have been 0 for the past couple years, no matter how well you are rated. Constant strategy changes and frequent layoffs. Binge and purge approach to staffing.

review_title: Citi is a good, solid company to work for, with internal opportunities. Just watch your back.
job_title: IT Systems Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
There are great learning opportunities and the potential for internal transfer to practically anywhere in the WORLD. It takes work and planning but it is possible. 
I recommend signing up for the 401k as soon as you're eligible. The company contributes too as long as you do. It hurts a bit at first when you think about what your take-home pay could be, but look to your future.
Their stated policies toward employees are very liberal and generous, but sometimes you need to politely remind your management about them.
cons:
You've heard the old saying, "It's not what you know, but who you know". Well, you'll most likely see it in action here. You can try to stand out and get past it, you can embrace it and try to turn it to your advantage (aka join the Dark Side LOL), you can accept/ignore it and just appreciate a steady job with little hope of promotion, or you can go elsewhere.
My department, at least, has had no salary increases or bonuses except, I thnk, my 2nd level up of management. That's always heartening and gives workers incentive to do a great job (sarcasm).
They can work you to almost no limit, using a policy in the Employee Handbook that goes something like, "An Officer of the Bank may have no set hours and no timeclock to punch, but is expected to maintain his/her job functions. This can mean you will need to work late hours and extra days on occasion". - If this happens to you, go with it maybe a few times, but then you will need to stand up for yourself and bring up another section of the Handbook, regarding Work/Life Balance.

review_title: It is what it is. Enter with your Eyes Open!
job_title: Analyst Programmer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Money, skills opportunity. Viewed well by other employers in local market. Can get lucky and get a good team.

review_title: Good if you are into Finance, horrible for IT guys

review_title: Interesting - but don't get too old...
pros: The pay was decent until "redundancy" hit me.  Then I was fired due to "business reasons".  Lost everything.  Hey, take a chance if you want to - why not...  You just might make it if you kiss up to the right people...
cons: When you get let go, you get "one phone call".... made just to you with HR on the line to explain what comes next.

review_title: Unlike anywhere else I have ever worked
pros: This company has serious scale...and the potential when they do finally get their s**t together is huge! I don't think that is going to happen any time soon though! The Australian office is a total joke
cons: Where do I start?In Australia the HR team was reduced to such a small function that it is ineffective. As a result a lot of very average people hiring more junior people exactly like them unsupervised. There is no strategy on the consumer side. Not working as a team, wasting massive amounts of money on vanity marketing sponsorships. An obsession with acquiring new customers, but losing customers at a much faster rate - which noone tries to address! Also tries to promote itself as a leader in terms of women in the workplace. The reality is they try to resist allowing any women returning from maternity leave to work part time. Every head regardless of hours worked counts as 'full-time', hence it is in the companies interest to minimise part-timers.Where they do get to work part-time( miraculously) they are expected to work on their days off consistently - my manager told me 'that is just the way things work here'. Honestly so many staff who have been there too long - it needs a huge clear out and a restructure to bring in fresh (and current) ideas...just too institutionalised.

review_title: Retention is the hardest job on a phone.
pros: The ability to make bonuses is the ONLY thing that makes this job doable. Time off and health benefits are decent. Having "retention" on your resume will open doors, because it is the hardest job on the phone and you need to have an understanding of almost all areas of the business to be successful. Also your oral communication skills will need to be excellent if you want to do well, people who speak poorly will have a very hard time in this position.
cons:
The catch with the bonuses is that you must be in your role for 6 months after you hit the floor before you even start seeing the real money. More than half of my training class has left before they met this criteria. So they worked hard and never saw a dime for their efforts. That is most likely what the higher ups in corporate intended, because the bonus payouts can almost double the salary. But it's just not worth it.

You need to retain on average every other account (50%), so imagine trying to convince 50 people out of 100 to do the exact opposite thing they initially called to do. The turnover rate for this position is incredible.

Need a much higher Base Pay to make this job worth it. You will typically start between 25-30k, the salary should be 35-45k.

If you can get into another position within the business, Citi is a great company. But this position will make you hate life.

review_title: Not really interested in more than band-aids for issues.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The campus was beautiful! The trainers were very nice and knowledgeable. Our site leaders were fairly decent people too.
cons: Everything is all about numbers. How many calls you take. How quickly you can dump the client off the phone. How much extra you can sell the client is far more valued than what you can actually assist the customer with.      Was told to stop ending the call with "is there anything else I can help you with?" because people could tell I meant it and actually wanted me to deal with another issue. Motto was basically ONE AND DONE.... You had to do a sales offer even though the client ONLY wanted customer service, then you helped with a single problem and then got them off the phone in 189 seconds!!  You fixed one problem or issue only and got rid of them. Night shift pays the best but you deal with a lot of computers issues that can take way longer than 189 seconds to clear up. Highly stressful. unless you are one of those people who really don't care about truly helping others anyway.     The other real objection is nothing ever stays the same 2 weeks in a row. Someone gets a brainy idea about a service or new way to handle an issue and they inplement and then cancel half the time without any advance warning. Really frustrating to both reps and clients.Our team had only 5 monthly meetings in 12 months ! How does that help the reps do their jobs properly? Frustration level very high.In the 2 years I was there only 4 people were left from our original 32 member class.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Very international and diverse group of people.  One of the best trading floors overlooking the West-side highway.  You can be creative, and there is very little micro-management.
cons: Poor management.  No unity within the team.  People are only concerned of themselves and their title and status in company.  You need to 'play politics' to go up the rankings.

pros: Most supervisors are paying attention and do their jobs well.  Promotion is possible if you do good work.  Pay is acceptable, we had a pay freeze, then some small incremental raises.  This was after the Crash of 2008.  Training was good.
cons:
No one is allowed two days off together, except supervisors.  Promotion is often the result of kissing butt, resulting in some very poor supervisors.  

Time off can be hard to get approved, and you are given a very small "bank" at the beginning of your hire, and the beginning of the year, from which you are to draw all of your absences and time off.  I would be sick, and come in after half a day off, or leave after a few hours to save my time, and be talked to about how I must not really be sick, if I didn't take a full day.  When I started taking a full day instead, I quickly depleted the bank, so it was a catch-022.  Yet, I was also talked-to about coming to work sick, since I could pass it along, and should stay home if I was ill.

Another issue was the call scoring.  A new metric was introduced that had everyone in the center failing -- literally everyone.  It was, and still may be, very much based in the OPINION of the listener, on such things as, "did you establish a relationship with the caller" and such wishy-washy points that allowed managers to trash the employees they didn't like.  I was an award-winning employee, for my call quality, and could barely pass, occasionally.  Most people in my section had failed, failed failed, despite being conscientious long-term, experienced employees, many who had almost never failed a call scoring.  One was failed for "hitting all the points, but not in the right order." 

The order of the score sheet had never been brought up to anyone else I talked to about her review, and my passing calls were often not "in order" of the score sheet requirements.  Calls just don't flow by script, and in fact, we could be dinged for sounding like we were following a script.  Another catch-22 for her.   I watched people with 12-20 years with Citi quit or retire, because they suddenly could not pass a call, and many were crushed, would be in tears.  I hope this scoring system has been abandoned.

The list of items on the score list was enormous.  One of the agents printed it out as points to follow, on calls, and there were more than 20 items on it.  But calls over 20 minutes long would not be scored (too long for the managers to listen to) and those would of course be the calls that all points could have been met on...

Another supervisor was fired, while I was in that section, for abuse.  However, it had taken a year of complaints by various employees.  Again, I saw employees in tears, and crushed, after being with him, having been called stupid, and verbally berated in an entirely unprofessional and unacceptable way. Such complaints should have been taken seriously much sooner.

Dialer is run out of Kansas City (or was) and often started repeating, or sending us other inappropriate calls.  This was constant and rarely addressed, and on a Saturday, could not be addressed at all.  It is frustrating to re-call people you just talked with, and have to hang up on all of them, because no one in Kansas City worked on Saturday.  This was NOT an uncommon issue.

pros: Work/Life balance is good, in fact they are heavy into Flexible Work Schedules, I am allowed to work from home two days a week, which is great.  Other benefits are good as well, 401k, vacation, sick time, etc. The work is challenging most times.
cons: Citi prides itself on being a meritocracy, which is supposed to mean - "A system in which advancement is based on individual ability or achievement." But that is just not true, even after getting a very good year end performance evaluation, I did not receive a pay raise, for the THIRD YEAR IN A ROW!!!!! The usual nonsense about not having money in the budget, yeah right, I'm sure my manager got a nice raise and a bonus too!

Management constantly fails to live up to any promises of advancement or growth. Mentoring from manager is focuses on advancing said manager and not on you. review_title: Bureaucratic Beast of Company Which Does Not Value Employees
pros: If you are someone who can "work" the system. If you are a younger worker, if you are a man, if you are not a minority, if you are not disabled, you /might/ be able to work your way up to a more or less livable wage.
cons: Very poor work-life balance.  In the almost 9 years I worked for a Citi site  /no/ women were promoted to higher management positions... none. Although men with less experience, less education, who fell into the magical zone of 25-35 years of age, white, adhering overwhelmingly to a particular religious preference were promoted and mentored. The HR department saw employee concerns as bothersome (with some notable exceptions). Senior management excelled at talking the talk, few actually walked the walk (with a few exceptional and notable examples... of whom there has been no equal).  Merit pay is really not merit pay. Senior management decides based upon budget how many can receive top evaluations that merit pay increases. In a department that employs say 100 people this can mean that only a handful can obtain a score to merit an increase, regardless of whether their performance merits one or not. They start with what the department will receive in terms of budget and then they work their numbers from there. One poor manager can truly mess up an employee's life. Senior managers express the view that employee benefits are "given" to employees rather than earned compensation. Bureaucracy is be all, end all, to the point where attempts at quality control reviews earned violation warnings retroactive to the employees being notified of policy changes on call handling, and even created a circumstance where employees could be coached on a "high risk" call, but the employees were told they had to sign they had reviewed the call handling with their manager, but they were not permitted to see or to understand what the high-risk factor was, to listen to the call, or to know any of the reasons why (or to even be able to review what was written on the reverse side of the document presented for their signature). If an employee balked or raised questions about these sorts of practices, they risked being labeled as "difficult." Older and longer term employees would have goal posts for performance changed in apparent move by management to rid the company of more highly compensated longer term employees in favor of younger, newer hires (even giving newer hires different performance goals to meet for call handling).

review_title: Get in, get good experience, and leave
pros: Good pay, ability to work from home, interesting work at times, nice workers and managers if you luck out, otherwise you're screwed.
cons:
Very cutthroat and political environment. You have to watch your back and worry about someone pulling something on you or your team. Long pointless meetings, low morale. 

No incentive to care as you can be re-organized out of your role. I've seen departments disappear overnight and people hold their breath when am email comes with an important announcement. Is this the end? Is my manager fired? Am I? These are questions you'll soon learn to ask working at Citi. But don't worry, they're just making some fine adjustments so we can work more efficiently and cohesively.

When you have directors asking you to frame questions a certain way so we can prove your department's value to senior directors, you know you have a problem. Very hard to move up, you have to come externally to have a higher title. Instead of employees, we now use contractors for a lot of roles, but you have to worry if they're planning to replace you with them.

If you're still reading this, you're probably going to take the job here despite all this. I don't blame you, it pay well and might be close to you and could get you some banking experience. BE SURE YOU INTERVIEW YOUR DIRECT MANAGER! Find out how they work and their attitude towards their subordinates. I have seen some real crummy managers who are not flexible and micromanage everything. Nothing sucks more than seeing coworkers live it up with a manager that's great while you're stuck with one telling you off for something stupid like going to the restroom. While I'm exaggerating about the restroom, I hope you get my point.
